lg.l: THROUGH the wide tracts of life, in every trade,
What numbers toil with faculties decay'd?
Worn out, yet eager,— in the race they run,
And never learn—when proper to have done.
What need of proofs? Ev'n Authors do the same,
And rather than desist decline in fame.
Like Gamesters thrive at first; then bolder grow,
And hazard all upon one desp'rate throw.
This truth to feel, perhaps too much inclin'd,
Our Bard, long hackney'd, trembles there behind,
Lest he should prove—another VANISH'D MIND.
Long has this play lain hid, suppress'd by fears,
Beyond the critics rule, ABOVE NINE YEARS!
And now he comes, 'tis the plain simple truth,
This night to answer for his sins of youth.
The piece, you'll say, should now perfection bear;
But who can reach it after all his care?
He paints no monsters for ill judg'd applause:
Life he has view'd, and from that source he draws.
Here are no fools, the Drama's standing jest!
And WELCHMEN now, NORTH-BRITONS too may rest.
HIBERNIA'S SONS shall here excite no wonder,
Nor shall ST. PATRICK blush to hear them blunder.
By other arts he strives your taste to hit,
Some plot, some character; he hopes, some wit.
And if this piece should please you like the past;
Ye Brother Bards! forgive him:—'tis his last.
Lost are the friends who lent their aid before;
ROSCIUS retires, and BARRY is no more.
Harmonious BARRY! with what varied art
His grief, rage, tenderness assail'd the heart?
Of plaintive OTWAY now no more the boast!
And SHAKESPEARE grieves for his OTHELLO lost.
Oft on this spot the tuneful swan expir'd,
Warbling his grief;—you listen'd and admir
'Twas then but fancy'd woe; now ev'ry Muse,
Her lyre unstrung, with tears his urn bedews.
From this night's scenes e'n WOODWARD too is fled,
Stretch'd by pale sickness on his languid bed,

Nor can THALIA raise her FAVOURITE'sMr. WOODWARD was to have played the part of DASHWOULD: in his last illness he lamented to the Author, that he could not close his theatrical life with that character: he died a few weeks after the play appeared; for years the life of the comic scene, and in his end regretted as a worthy and an honest man. head.
For them our Author lov'd the tale to weave;
He feels their loss; and now he takes his leave;
Sees new performers in succession spring,
And hopes new poets will expand their wing.
Beneath your smile his leaf of laurel grew;
Gladly he'd keep it;—for 'twas giv'n by you.
But if too weak his art, if wild his aim,
On favours past he builds no idle claim:
To you once more he boldly dares to trust;
HEAR, and pronounce;—he KNOWS you will be just.

head.stage: the House of Sir JOHN MILLAMOUR.

sp.speaker: BYGROVE.
sp.p: WHY then I'd marry again, and disinherit him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Brother Bygrove, you think too severely in these matters.

sp.speaker: BYGROVE.
sp.p: Severely, Sir John? If I had a mind that my son should marry, why should he not do as I would have him?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Allowance must be made for inclination. The success of our children depends upon the manner, in which we set them out in the world. They are like bowls which, if deliver'd out of hand with a due regard to their bias, our aim is answer'd, if otherwise, they are short or wide of the mark in view, or perhaps rush wildly out of the green.

sp.speaker: BYGROVE.
sp.p: Well argued, truly! he that should obey is to judge for himself, and you that are his governor, are to be directed by him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Why he is chiefly interested in the end, and the choice of the means may be fairly left to himself. I can't but be tender of George; a plant of my own rearing, and the tree will hereafter be known by its fruit.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: It is a tree that will bear nothing without grafting; and if I could not inoculate what will make it thrive and flourish, it should not incumber a foot of my land.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Your system and mine differ widely, Brother Bygrove. My son is of a large and liberal understanding, and I a father of mild authority.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Authority!—your son's word is a law to you. Now there is my young graceless; he is in the army, and why? Because I chose it. I had a mind he should serve; and so he went to be shot at. No arguing with me. If I see any thing wrong, I accost him directly: Look ye, Sir, do you think to go on in this fashion? Not during my life, I promise you: I will acknowledge you no longer than you prove worthy; and if you can't discern what is befitting you, I at least will judge what is proper on my part.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Well, George and I have lived together as friends. From a boy, I endeavoured to subject him rather to his reason, than his fears. If any little irregularity happened, he was no sooner sensible of it, than his cheek coloured, and the blush of youth not only looked decent, but expressed an ingenuous and well-disposed mind.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: But the consequence of all this? Has he a settled opinion? a fixed principle for a moment? He is grown up in caprice; his judgment has not vigour to be decisive upon the merest trifle; he is destracted by little things, and of course is perishing by little and little.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! no; all from a good cause; his knowledge of life occasions quick reflection: quick reflection shews things in a variety of lights. I am not angry. He will settle in the world; you will see him married before long.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: In what a variety of lights his wife will appear to him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I beg your pardon for a moment. I see person there. Charles, Charles, this way.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Well, Charles, what is he about?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Very busy, Sir, a thousand things in hand.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And all at the same time, I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: We have a deal to employ us, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Have you sounded him in regard to what I mentioned last night?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: That's what I wanted to tell your Honour. Last night, Sir, as he was going to bed, I touch'd upon the subject; dropt a hint or two, that it is now time to think of raising heirs to himself; enlarged upon the comforts of matrimony, and I think with no small degree of eloquence.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: The fellow is laughing at you.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Well, and how? What effect?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: A very visible effect, Sir. This morning early, my master rings his bell. Charles, says he, I have been considering what you said last night: I shall pay a visit to the young ladies, and, I believe, I shall marry one of them.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: There, Mr. Bygrove; I am for ever obliged to you, Charles. Well, go on.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: I fly immediately to get him his things to dress, and return in an instant. Charles, says he, then tossed himself back in his chair, beat the ground with his heel, and fell a reading. Won't your Honour get ready to visit the young ladies?—The ladies? what ladies, you blockhead?—Lady Bell, and Lady Jane, your Honour, Mrs. Bromley's handsome nieces. Po! you're a numskull, says he, with an oblique kind of a smile; stretched his arms, yawned, talked to himself, and bade me go about my business.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p:
I knew it would end so. There is not a crane-neck carriage in town can give a short turn with
him. He will continue going on from one thing to another, and end in nothing at last.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: This is provoking. Any body with him this morning?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: He has had a power of people with him, Sir—A commission-broker, to sell him a company in a marching regiment; the Mayor of a borough, about a seat in parliament. And there are several with him now, Sir. There is Sir Harry Lovewit, and—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Aye! Sir Harry! I am glad he is of age, and that I am no longer his guardian. He has not had a new idea in his head since he was five years old, and yet the blockhead affects to be lively. He runs after wits, who do nothing but laugh at him. He repeats scraps and sentences; all memory and no understanding; a mere retailer of what falls from other people, and with that stock he sets up for a wit.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: He is with my master, Sir; and there is Mr. Malvil, and Mr. Dashwould, and—(bell rings) —He rings, Sir: you will pardon me; I must be gone, Sir.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And that fellow, Dashwould; he is the ruin of your son, and of poor Sir Harry into the bargain. He is the Merry Andrew of the town: honour has no restraint upon him; truth he sets at nought, and friendship he is ever ready to sacrifice to a joke.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Po! mere innocent pleasantry. Dashwould has no harm in him.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No harm in him? I grant you the fellow has a quick sense of the ridiculous, and draws a character with a lucky hit. But every thing is distorted by him. He has wit to ridicule you; invention to frame a story of you; humour to help it about, and when he has set the town a laughing, he puts on a familiar air, and shakes you by the hand.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! I shall certainly expire one day, in a fit of laughing.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: What fool's errand brings him hither?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: That fellow, Dashwould, will be the death of me. The very spirit of whim, wit, humour, and raillery possess him.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Ay! wit and humour for the meridian of your understanding.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: By the shade of Rablais, he is the most entertaining creature! He has play'd off such a fire-work of wit. I'll tell you what he said this moment.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No, Sir, no; if you are a pedlar in smart sayings and brisk repartees, we don't desire you to unpack for us.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: A plague on him for an agreeable devil! And then the rogue has so much ease.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Yes, the ease of an executioner. He puts all to death without remorse. He laughs at every thing, as if Heaven intended to make its own work ridiculous. He has no relish for beauty, natural or moral. He is in love with deformity, and never better pleased, than when he has most reason to find fault.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: There is a picture of as harsh features as any in Dashwould's whole collection.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: But the picture is true. No exaggerationin it.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: He gave us a miniature of you, this morning, my dear guardian, and you shall have it. Dashwould has made a discovery, Sir John. What reason do you think he gives for Mr. Bygrove's railing for ever at your son's inconstancy of temper?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Ay, now! now!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: You positively shall hear it. Mr. Bygrove's desires being all rusted to a point, looking directly toward the land of matrimony—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Matrimony! now gild the pill with humour, and down it goes.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Dashwould has found you out. Mr. Bygrove's desires being all collected and fixed on matrimony, he rails at the variety of my friend Milamour's whimsies, like Sir George Bumper, with chalkstones on his knuckles, as big as nutmegs, hobbling along and thanking Doctor Le Fevre that he has no small humours flying about him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: That's a discovery indeed.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Sir John, can you mind what such a fellow as Dashwould says? Every thing that passes through the medium of his fancy appears deformed, as the straitest stick looks crooked in troubled water.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Well dashed out, upon my soul, with tolerable spleen, and some vivacity.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Po!—if you had taken my advice, Sir Harry and renounced his acquaintance long ago, you had been now a young man coming into life, with some promise of a character. Continue in dissipation, Sir. For my part it is a rule with me, neither to give nor take a joke.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Ho! ho! ho! a pleasant rule, positively —ho! ho! ho! Dashwould shall have it this moment; do you take the consequence; and in the mean time, I'll leave you to the practice of your social humour.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: It is such coxcombs as that butterfly, that encourage him to fix his pasquinades upon every man's character. Matrimony!—a licentious— No, Sir John, I still cherish the memory of your sister; she was the best of wives; 'sdeath, interrupted again by that—No, it's my friend Malvil; he is a man of true value.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Dashwould says, he is a compound of false charity, and real malice.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And it is enough for you that Dashwould says it. Malvil is a man of honour, Sir; and an enemy to all scandal, though wit prove a palateable ingredient in the poison.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Intolerable! there is no being safe where he is. A licentious railer! All truth, all morality sacrificed to a jest: nothing sacred from his buffoonery.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: I told you, Sir John, how it is.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Oh! such indiscriminate satire!

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Yes, the fellow runs a muck, and nothing escapes him.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: There is no enduring it. Ridicule is a very unfair weapon, Mr. Bygrove: it is by no means the test of truth, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Nay, but you are too grave about this matter.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Too grave! Shall he wantonly stab the reputation of his neighbour, and then tell you it was in jest? For my part, I had rather throw a veil over the infirmities of my friend, than seek a malicious pleasure in the detection. That's my way of thinking.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I fancy you are right. This son of mine does so perplex me.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Bygrove, give me leave. I am sorry to hear certain whispers about a friend of ours.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: About whom? the widow, Mrs. Bromley?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Oh! no, no; I have a great respect for her: though I—Pray don't you think she throws out the lure for a young husband?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: For a husband, yes, but not too young a one; you can serve my interest in that quarter.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I know it: rely upon my friendship. But have you heard nothing of an eminent Turkey merchant?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Mr. Freeport?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I say nothing: I don't like the affair: have you really heard nothing?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Not a syllable.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: So much the better: though it is fit you should be put upon your guard. Any money of yours in his hands?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Po! as safe as the bank.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I may be mistaken. I hope I am: I was in company the other night; several members of parliament present; they did not speak plainly; hints and inuendos only; you won't let it go any further. His seat in the house they all agreed, is perfectly convenient at this juncture. I hope the cloud will blow over.—I shall remember you with the widow.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: One good turn deserves another: I shan't be unmindful of your interest.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: There, now you hurt me: you know my delicacy: must friendship never act a disinterested part? I esteem you, Mr. Bygrove, and that's sufficient. Sir John, give me leave to say, the man who busies himself about other people's affairs, is a pragmatical character, and very dangerous in society.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: So I have been telling Sir John. But to laugh at every thing is the fashion of the age. A pleasant good-for-nothing fellow is by most people preferred to modest merit. A man like Dashwould, who runs on—So! here come Scandal in folio.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Sir John, I rejoice to see you. Mr. Bygrove, I kiss your hand. Malvil, have you been uneasy for any friend since?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Po! absurd!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I have been laughing with your son, Sir John. Pray have I told you about Sir Richard Doriland?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: You may spare him, Sir, he is a very worthy man.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He is so: great good-nature about him: I love Sir Richard. You know he was divorced from his wife; a good fine woman, but an invincible ideot.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Look ye there now, Mr. Bygrove!

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: My Lady Doriland, Sir, was always counted a very sensible woman.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: She was so; with too much spirit to be ever at ease, and a rage for pleasure, that broke the bubble as she grasped it. She fainted away upon hearing that Mrs. All-night had two card tables more than herself.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Inveterate malice!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: They waged war a whole winter, for the honour of having the greatest number of fools thinking of nothing but the odd trick. First, Mrs. All-night kept Sundays; her Ladyship did the same: Mrs. All-night had forty tables; her Ladyship rose to fifty. Then one added, then t'other; 'till every room in the house was cramm'd like the black hole at Calcutta; and at last, upon casting up the account, Sir Richard sold off fifteen hundred acres, to clear incumbrances.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ridiculous! and so they parted upon this?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Don't you know the history of that business?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Now mark him; now.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Tender of reputation, Malvil!—The story is well known. She was detected with—the little foreign Count—I call him the Salamander—I saw him sive times in one winter upon the back of the fire at Bath, for cheating at cards.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Go on, Sir, abuse every body. My Lady was perfectly innocent. I know the whole affair: a mere contrivance to lay the foundation of a divorce.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: So they gave our. Sir Richard did not care a nine-pin for her while she was his. You know his way: he despises what is in his possession, and languishes for what is not. Her Ladyship was no sooner married to—what's his name?—His father was a footman, and Madam Fortune, who every now and then loves a joke, sent him to the East Indies, and in a few years brought him back at the head of half a million, for the jest's sake.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mr. Dashwould, upon my word, Sir, — Families to be run down in this manner!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Mushroon was his name: my Lady Doriland was no sooner married to him, but up to his eyes Sir Richard was in love with her. He dressed at her; sighed at her; danced at her; she is now libelled in the Commons, and Sir Richard has a crim. con. against him in the King's Bench.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Pshaw! I shall stay no longer to hear this strain of defamation.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Malvil, must you leave us? A pleasant character this same Mr. Malvil.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: He has a proper regard for his friends, Sir.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Yes, but he is often present where their characters are canvassed, and is anxious about whispers which nobody has heard. He knows the use of hypocrisy better than a Court Chaplain.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: There, call honesty by a burlesque name, and so pervert every thing.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Things are more perverted, Mr. Bygrove, when such men as Malvil make their vices do their work, under a mask of goodness; and with that stroke we'll dismiss his character.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay, very right; my brother Bygrove has a regard for him, and to change the subject. My son, Mr. Dashwould, what does he intend?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Up to the eyes in love with Lady Bell, and determined to marry her.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I told you so, Mr. Bygrove; I told you, you would soon see him settled in the world. Mr. Dashwould, I thank you; I'll step and consirm George in his resolution.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: A good-natur'd man, Sir John, and does not want credulity,

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Ay! there, the moment his back is turned.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Gulliver's Travels is a true history to him. His son has strange flights. First he was to be a lawyer; bought chambers in the Temple, eat his commons, and was called to the bar. Then the law is a damn'd dry, municipal study; the army is fitter for a gentleman; and as he was going to the Waroffice to take out his commission, he saw my Lord Chancellor's coach go by; in an instant, back to the Temple, and no sooner there, Po! pox! hang the law; better marry, and live like a gentleman. Now marriage is a galling yoke, and he does not know what he'll do. He calls his man Charles; sends him away; walks about the room; sits down; asks a question; thinks of something else; talks to himself, sings, whistles, lively, pensive, pleasant, and melancholy in an instant. He approves, sinds fault; he will, he will not; and in short, the man does not know his own mind for half a second.—Here comes Sir John.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You find him disposed to marry, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I hope so; he wavers a little; but still I—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Po! I have no patience; my advice has been all lost upon you. I wish it may end well. A good morning, Sir John.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Mr. Bygrove, your's: Sir John will defend you in your absence.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: If you will forget your friends in their absence, it is the greatest favour you can bestow upon them.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Did I ever tell you what happened to him last summer, at Tunbridge?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Excuse me for the present: This light young man! I must step, and talk with my lawyer.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I'll walk part of the way with you. A strange medley this same Mr. Bygrove: with something like wit, he is always abusing wit.—You must know, last summer, at Tunbridge—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Another time, if you please.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The story is worth your hearing: a party of us dined at the Sussex—

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Mr. Dashwould! Mr. Dashwould!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: What's the matter, Charles?

sp.speaker: CHA.
sp.p: My master desires you won't go.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Hey! what going to leave us?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Only a step with Sir John. Strange vagaries in your master's head, Charles!—Sir Harry! going to wait upon Miss Neville, I suppose. She has beauty, and you have a heart.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Pshaw! there you wrong me now! Why will you?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Very well; be it so; I can't see to be sure; but take my word for it, you will marry that girl. Come, I follow you.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I must not part with you: I had rather lose the whole College of Physicians.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: March on, Sir Harry.— (turns to Charles) Did you ever see such a Baronet? This fellow, Charles, is as ridiculous himself as any of them.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Now have I but one man in the house, and he will be fifty different men in a moment. Hurry! hurry! nothing but hurry! Get me this; get me that; get me t'other; bring me the blue and silver; scoundrel! what do you fetch me this for? let me have the brown and gold. A poor servant does not know which way to turn himself in this house.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Well, Richard, what are you about?

sp.speaker: RICH.
sp.p: Why a man in a whirlwind may as well tell what he is about. Going to order the coachman to put up. He intends to change his dress, and walk to the Temple.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: What does he mean by talking of the Temple again? I hope we are not going to take to our studies once more. I hate the law: there is not a footman in the Temple has a grain of taste. All mere lawyers! They have not an idea out of the profession.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Richard! Richard! where is he gone?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: What's in the wind now?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: The wind's in another quarter. He has been writing verses as he calls them, ever since the company left him. He has torn a quire of paper, I believe, and now he wants the carriage directly.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Run and order it. I had rather be a country curate, than go on in this manner. (bell rings) What is he at now?

sp.speaker: MILLAMOUR.
sp.p: Charles:—who answers there?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Ay; now for the old work.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Is the chariot ready?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: At the door, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Do you step to Mrs. Bromley's, and—perhaps it would be better to—No, do you step, Charles, and—you need not mind it—another time will do as well.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: There again now: this is the way from morning to night.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: The sooner the better: I promised Sir John, and I will pay this visit. Lady Bell reigns sovereign of my heart. That vivacity of mind! "Quick as her eyes, and as unfix'd as those."

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: She is by far preferable to her sister, your Honour.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Po! you are illiterate in these matters. The sober graces of Lady Jane!—Lady Bell advances like a conqueror, and demands your heart: Lady Jane seems unconscious of her charms, and yet enslaves you deeper.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Which of them does your Honour think—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Which of'em, Charles? (reads a paper) "I look'd, and I sign'd, and I wish'd I could speak."

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Captain Bygrove, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: That's unlucky. I am not at home; tell him I went out an hour ago.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: My dear Bygrove, I longed to see you. But why that pensive air? Still in love, I suppose,

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: My dear Millamour, you have guessed it. I am in love, and I glory in my chains.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Shall I tell you a secret? I suspect myself, plaguily. Every thing is not as quiet here as it used to be.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Indulge the happy passion. Let wits and libertines say what they will; 'there is no true happiness, but in the married state.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Why I have thought much upon the subject of late, and with a certain refinement, I don't know but a man may fashion a complying girl to his taste of happiness. Virtuous himself, he confirms her in her virtue; constant, he secures her fidelity: and by continuing the lover, instead of commencing the tyrant husband, he wins from her the sweetest exertion of tenderness and love. I shall most positively marry. Who is your idol? My dear boy, impart.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: There I beg to be excused. You know my father. I must not presume to think for myself. I must contrive some stratagem to make him propose the match. Were it to move first from me, I should be obliged to decamp from before the town at once.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I wish you success. My resolution is taken, and with the most amiable of her sex. She romps about the room like one of the Graces; and deals about her wit with such a happy negligence—

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: An agreeable portrait, but mine is the very reverse. That equal serenity in all her ways! Wit she has, but without ostentation; and elegance itself seems the pure effect of nature.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I don't know whether that is not the true character for a wife. And pray, what progress have you made in her affections?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Enough to convince me that I am not quite unacceptable My dear Millamour, I had rather fold that girl in my arms, than kiss his Majesty's hand for the first regiment of guards.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I am a lost man, I shall most positively marry. We will wonder at each others felicity; and be the envy of all our acquaintance.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I am as good as my word, you see. Most noble Captain, your father was here this morning. A good agreeable old gentleman, and about as pleasant as a night mare. Millamour, whom do you think I met since I saw you?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Our friend Beverly, just imported from Paris, perfectly frenchified, and abusing every thing in this country— Oh! there is no breathing their English atmosphere.—Roast beef and liberty will be the death of me.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! poor Beverley! I saw him, last summer, at Paris, dressed in the stile of an English fox-hunter: he swore there was not a morsel to eat in their country; kept an opera-singer upon beef-steaks and oyster-sauce; drove to his villa every Saturday in a phaeton, and returned on the Monday, like a young Buck, just come upon town.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He has done his country great honour abroad.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: He will settle at home now: he is going to he married.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Yes, I hear he is in love, and much good may it do him. I wish I may die, if I know so ridiculous a thing as love.— My life!—My soul!—Hybla dwells upon her lips; extasy and bliss! blank verse and pastoral nonsense! In a I'ttle time, the man wonders what bewitched him: an arm chair after dinner, and a box and dice till five in the morning, make all the comforts of his life.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Very true! Love is a ridiculous passion indeed.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Do you take up arms against me? But a moment since, just as you came in, he was acknowledging to me—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p:
No, not I, truly; I acknowledge nothing.
Marriage is not to my taste, I promise you. The handsome wife!—she is all affectation; routs, drums, hurricanes, and intrigue!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And the ugly! she makes it up with good sense; pronounces upon wit! and talks you dead with maxims, characters, and reflections.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And the woman of high birth, she produces her pedigree, as her patent for vice and folly. "Seven's the main," and away goes your whole fortune.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Mere common place.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And the tender maukin! she doats upon you. Don't drink any more, my dear: you'll take cold near that window, my love; pray don't talk so much; you'll flurry your spirits—And then kisses you before company.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And the sick madam! she has the vapours, and finds that she has nerves.—"I wish I had none.'— But it is too true that I have nerves, as slight as so many hairs.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Ha! ha! the whole sex is divided into so many classes of folly.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Right! so it is. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: You play finely into one another's hands.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Now mark the champion of the sex!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Yes; he'll throw down the gauntlet for 'em.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Nay, decide it your own way. Since you won't hear, gentlemen, there is a clear stage for you.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Fare ye well, most noble Captain. A facetious companion! did you ever hear him say any thing?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: He is in for it; and my father would fain reduce me to the same condition with one of Mrs. Bromley's nieces. A good fine woman, Mrs. Bromley!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p:
Has been! Were she now to rub her cheek
with a white handkerchief, her roses and lilies would go to the clear starcher.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! and yet she sets up for the rival, of her nieces.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The young ladies are pretty well in their way too. Lady Bell has a brisk volubility of nothing, that she plays the pretty ideot with: and Lady Jane, a sly piece of formality, ready to go post for Scotland, with the first red-coat that asks her the question. We all dine at the Widow's to day, are you to be with us?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes, to meet you: the party will be diverting.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Observe old Bygrove. He pronounces with rigour upon the conduct of others, and hopes his own follies lie concealed. His whole struggle is to escape detection, He hoodwinks himself, and thinks he blinds you. Positive and dogmatical in his opinions, yet a dupe to the designs of others; and flattering himself that a peevish and censorious spirit hides every defect, he gives you the full ridicule of his character.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I have marked him before now.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Mark him with the widow: you will see him sighing for his deceased wife and Mrs. Bromley's charms at the same time. One eye shall weep for the dead, and the other ogle the living.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—And then Malvil laying siege to Miss Neville!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Miss Neville is the best of them. Mrs. Bromley has taken her into her house, as a poor relation, whom she pities; and her pity is no more than the cruel art of tormenting an unhappy dependant upon her generosity.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: But she has generosity. She has promised Miss Neville a fortune of five thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And so the hook is baited for Malvil. The widow flings out that snare, to counteract Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Sir Harry!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Yes; he is in love with Miss Neville; and the best of the story is, he is afraid I shall think him ridiculous. If I say the word, and promise not to laugh at him, he breaks his mind at once. Miss Neville sees clearly that he admires her, and of course will never listen to Malvil. The self-interested designs of that fellow shall be disappointed.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Admirable! thou art a whimsical fellow. Come, I attend you. A pleasant group they are all together. It is as you say,
sp.l: Ours passions sicken, and our pleasures cloy;
A fool to laugh at, is the height of joy.

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. BROMLEY, and Miss NEVILLE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROMLEY.
sp.p: WHY, to be sure, Neville, there is something in what you say; one is so odd, and so I don't know how in a morning.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Certainly, madam; and then people of your turn, whose wit overflows in conversation, are liable to a waste of spirits, and the alteration appears sooner in them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: So it does: you observe very prettily upon things. Heigho! I am as faded as an old lutestring to-day.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: No indeed, madam, you look very tolerably, consideting.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Considering! she grows pert, I think.—I am glad you think me not altogether intolerable.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Tolerably! she is Lady Bell's prime agent (aside). Has Sir Harry given you hopes lately?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Sir Harry! I really don't understand why he is mentioned.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Do you think it will be a match? And have you made up your quarrel with Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: The sweetness of her disposition reconciles every thing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: And is Millamour reconciled to Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: There was only a slight mistake, which I explained.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Oh! you explained? that was prudently done; I am glad to hear this: and do you think he loves her? Tell me; tell me all. Why? why do you think he loves her?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: He cannot be insensible of her merit; and the other day he asked me if you were likely to approve of his proposing for Lady Bell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: And you told him.—Well!— what did you tell him?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: That you, no doubt, would be ready to promote the happiness of so amiable a young lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You told him so? (rises and walks about) And so you are turned match-maker: you busy yourself in my family?—Hey!—Mrs. Start-up! you are dizened out, I think: my wardrobe has supplied you.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Your pardon, ma'am: I had these things in the country, when you first shewed so much goodness to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: What airs! you know I hate to see creatures give themselves airs. Was not I obliged to provide you with every thing?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: You have been very kind; I always acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Acknowledge it! Does not every body know it.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am. I dare say every body does know it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: That's maliciously said: I can spy a sneer upon that false face. You suppose I have made my brags. That's what lurks in your ambiguous meaning. I deserve it: deliver me from poor relations.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Now the storm begins! I am sure I have said nothing to offend you. I am helpless, it is true, but your relation, and by that tie a gentlewoman still.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I made you a gentlewoman. Did not I take you up in the country, where you lived in the parsonage-house, you, and your sister, with no other company to converse with, than the melancholy tomb-stones, where you read the high and mighty characters of John Hodge, and Deborah his wife? While your father's miserable horse, worn to a shadow with carrying double to the next markettown, limped about, with a dull alms begging eye in quest of the wretched sustenance, that grew thriftily between the graves? Did not I take you out of your misery?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: You did, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Did not I bring you home to the great house?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: You did, ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: And I am finely thanked for it. Warm the snake, and it will turn upon you.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I cannot bear to be insulted thus!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: So! your spirit is humbled, is it?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p:
Give me leave to tell you, madam, that when people of superior fortune, whom Providence
has enabled to bestow obligations, claim a right, from the favours they confer, to tyrannize over the hopes and fears of a mind in distress; they exercise a cruelty more barbarous than any in the whole history of human malice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Is this your gratitude?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I could be thankful for happiness, if you permitted me to enjoy it: but when I find myself, under colour of protection, made the sport of every sudden whim; I have a spirit, madam, that can distinguish between real benevolence, and the pride of riches.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: O brave! that is your spirit!

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: A spirit, give me leave to say, that would rather, in any obscure corner, submit to drudgery, for a slender pittance, than continue to be an unhappy subject, for cruelty to try its experiments upon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I faney I have been too violent. After all this sower, I must sweeten her a little. Come, dry up your tears: you know I am goodnatured in the main. I am only jealous, that you dont't seem to love me.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Were that left to my own heart, every principle there would attach me to you. But to be dunned for gratitude!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You are right; the observation is very just: I am in the wrong.—Come, let us be friends, I have a great regard for you, Neville. (walks aside) The creature should visit with me, only she looks so well—How! did not I hear Mr. Malvil's voice? yes, it is he; I am visible; I am at home; shew him in. Walk in, Mr. Malvil.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: To a person of sentiment, like you, madam, a visit is paid with pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You are very good to me. Neville, do you step and bring me the letter that lies upon my table (Exit Miss Neville) I am obliged to go out this morning. (smiles at Malvil) She looks mighty well: I have been speaking for you: our scheme will take. Sir Harry will not be able to rival you: she will be your reward for all your services to me.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Your generosity is above all praise, and so I was saying this moment to Mr. Bygrove: he is coming to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: That's unlucky: I wanted to have some talk with you: well, have you seen Millamour▪

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Yes, and I find him apt: I have hopes of succeding.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Hush!—not so loud!—you think me mad, I believe. May I hazard myself with that wild man?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Your virtue will reclaim him. I have a friendship for Millamour, and that is my reason for counteracting the designs of my friend Bygrove.—Mr. Bygrove has desired me to speak favourably of him to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Oh! but he kept his last wife mew'd up in the country; I should certainly expire in the country.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Why, I can't say much for a country life: you are perfectly right. Rooks and crows about your house; fox-hounds in full cry all the morning; the country 'squires as noisy at dinner as their own hounds; disputes about the game; commissioners of turnpikes, justices of the peace, and pedigrees of horses; Oroonoko, brother to White Surry, got by Brisk Lightning, his dam by Bold Thunder. —That's the whole of their conversation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Deliver me! it would be the death of me. But don't tell Mr. Bygrove: amuse him with hopes.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: He is a very worthy man. I am sorry to see some oddities in him; but that is very common in life. Vices always border upon virtues. Dash-would says, —but there is no believing his slander;— he says Mr. Bygrove's sorrow for his deceased wife, is all mere artisice, to weep himfelf into the good graces of another. But I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I hear him coming. Do you go and take care of your interest with Neville.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I obey your commands.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I shall make her fortune five thoufand. Be sure you speak to Millamour. Go, go; success attend you.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: This attention to one in my forlorn state is so obliging—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: It is a favour on your part to receive alost, dejected, spiritless—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I admire your sensibility, Mr. Bygrove. That tender look, which you are for ever casting back to a beloved, but irrecoverable object, shews so amiable a sorrow! oh! there is something exquisite in virtuous affection.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Is this the letter you want, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I thank you, Neville. Yes, there is a luxury in hankering after a valuable person, who has been snatched away. I have found a pleasing indulgence in contemplations of that sort; have not I, Neville?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Ma'am! are you deaf? Are you stupid? I was telling Mr. Bygrove, what a taking I was in, when poor dear Mr. Bromley died.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I was not with you then, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Was not with me! what memories some folks have!—Go, and try if you can recover your memory: leave the room.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Ungenerous, narrow minded woman!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Oh! you little know what a profusion of goodness I have lavished on that creature. She returns it all with sullenness, with ill humour; with aversion. She perfectly remembers the affliction I was in, when I lost the best of men.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: I have had my trials too. Heigho!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I beg your pardon: I am recalling your afflictions: you should not give way; you should struggle a little. Heaven knows how I have struggled. I have appeared, indeed, with an air, but it was all struggling. (looks and smiles) I could divert you this morning. Do you know that your son is in love with lady Jane?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: In love! has he said any thing?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I don't know as to that; but I can see what is working in his heart. He is above stairs now: I don't half like his choice: Lady Bell is the proper match for him, and her fortune is the best. An estate, you know, must come to her, by the family settlement. You should direct his choice.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: This comes of his presuming to think for himself. Has he declared himself?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I fancy not; but he hinted something to me, about a match in my family.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Why, a match in your family has diverted me of late—Heigho!—It is the only thing that has entertained me for a long time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I have had my fancies too. I should like to talk further, but I am engaged abroad this morning. Can I set you down? Will you trust yourselt with me?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: You encourage a smile, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: We shall be the town talk: but let them talk: what need we mind? I will just step and say a word to Neville—You should not be too solitary.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: So my friends tell me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I shall be with you in a moment. (returns) Do you know that we are very like each other in our tempers? After all, that is the true foundation of lasting friendships. Poor, dear Mr. Bromley! (going, returns) It was similitude of temper brought us together; and if ever I could be prevailed upon again, similitude of temper must do it. Well, you have diverted me this morning. Here comes your son, talk to him now.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what brings you to this house?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: A morning visit, Sir; merely to kill half an hour.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: There is nothing I hate so much as hypocrisy. I know your errand; you must pretend to be in love.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: I, Sir!

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: What have you been saying to Lady Jane? I thought I had cautioned you against presuming to think for yourself.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: You have been very kind in that way.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: See what comes of your friend Millamour's being left to his own discretion. The ass in the fable, divided in his choice, and still doubting on, till it is too late to resolve, gives but a faint image of him

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: And if I, Sir, to avoid his irresolution—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p:
You are in the opposite extreme: he thinks too much and never decides. You never think at
all, and so resolve without judgment. Take the advice of your friends before you come here to play the antic tricks of love; to kneel, cringe, fawn, flatter, and make yourself ridiculous. Do you know enough of the world to judge for yourself? Can you tell what they are all doing in the gay sphere of life? The young are all bred up under the veterans of vice and folly. The see their mothers with autumnal faces, playing the agreeable, and forgeting that they are no longer young. The men are advanced beyond all former bounds, and the women press close aster them. A club for the ladies! intrepidity is now the female charm: to compleat their career, there is nothing left but to build a turf Coterie, at Newmarket, and ride their own matches, over the four mile course.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: An admirable picture, Sir; Dash-would could not colour it higher.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Dashwould! an indiscriminate railer! I speak for your good, and remember, I tell you, you know nothing of the world. After all, Sir; Lady Bell is the person I wish to see you married to:—go, and pay your addresses to her. I will settle that matter for you: you may then marry the person, to whom you have not degraded yourself, by pining, sighing, love vetses, and I know not what.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: This is all unaccountable to me, Sir. If you will but hear me—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No, Sir, no; I won't allow you to fetch a single sigh, till I say the word; when I give leave, you may then go and sigh till your heart is ready to break. I'll hear no more: no parlying with me. Leave the house, this moment.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: I obey.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I interrupt you.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No, no; I am glad to see you. Well, have you had any opportunity with the widow?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I have; she surprizes me a little: she has dropt the mask. I did not think she had been so eager to marry. We had some talk about you. You know my heart: I am always true to my friends: I see but one difficulty: she will never agree to live in the country.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: The lover need not dispute that point, whatever the husband may do hereafter.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Very true; and besides, though I am not inclined, with the malicious part of the world, to suspect her virtue, yet this town has temptations. It grieves me to see the ways of this great city; fine women without principle; friends without sincerity: marriages to day, divorces to-morrow; whole estates set upon the cast of a die; masquerades without wit or humour; new comedies that make you cry, and tragedies that put you to sleep: It grieves me to see all this. You are in the right to prefer good sense and tranquility in the country.

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. BROMLEY, and Miss NEVILLE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, gentlemen. Neville, mind what I say to you: don't let those giddy girls go out in my absence; to walk in the Green Park, or run to hideous painters, under pretence of seeing odious pictures, that they may have an interview with more odious originals. Keep them at home; I will reward your pains. Allons, Mr. Bygrove. (Exit BYGROVE.) Come, Mr. Malvil.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Had not I better stay, and—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: No, no; come now, you may return to her.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: You see that I am torn from you; but I shall return as soon as possible.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p:
Tyrannical woman! some virtues she has; but they are overshadowed by their opposite qualities. Her love of praise, is a gross appetite
of flattery. She oppresses with kindness, and her very civilities are sure to be disobliging. Oh! state of dependance! for mere support, to be subject every hour to caprice and arrogance!—Is it pride that makes me feel with this sensibillity?—No, my heart can answer it is not. I can bow to the hand that relives me; but I cannot stoop to the servile office of pampering vanity and ostentation, with low and fulsome flattery. What does Lady Bell mean by talking to me of Sir Harry? She does it—I know her goodness—she does it to soften affliction, and, if possible, divert a mind depressed with sorrow. Sir Harry never threw away a thought on me. He behaves, indeed, with marked civility; but I don't know what to think of him. I must not aspire too high: no, I have no pretensions.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Miss Neville, I am very angry with you. What is the matter? Has any thing made you uneasy?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: No; I am not remarkable for high spirits, you know.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Why would not you give us your company? How can you be so cross? That sister of mine is the veriest madcap!

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Lady Bell is rather lively to be sure.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: But when she once begins, she hazards every thing, and talks sometimes like a very libertine.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: The overflowing of gaiety, and good humour.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p:
I wish she would restrain herself a little. Madam La Rouge is with her: she has the sweetest Point eyes ever beheld. I was endeavouring to cheapen it, but Lady Bell was so troublesome;
she called me a thousand prudes, and will have it that nothing runs in my head but a lover.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I don't know but she may be right. We are apt to deceive ourselves. We talk of vapours, and fidgets, and retirement, but it is often artful, sly, insinuating man, that lurks at the bottom.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Well, I vow you'll make me hate you.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Has Captain Bygrove made no disturbance in your heart?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: How can you? You are as great a plague as my sister. As I live and breathe, the giddy romp is coming. You must take my part.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.

l.hi: Yes, I'm in love, I own it now,
And Caelia has undone me;
And yet, I swear, I can't tell how,
The pleasing plague stole on me.

sp.p: What would I give to have some miserable swain talk in that style of me? "Belinda has undone me;" charming!

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: A lively imagination is a blessing, and you are happy, Lady Bell.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I am so: but then I am not talked of: I am losing all my time.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Why, you bold creature! I hate to hear you talk with so much intrepidity.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Prudery! my dear sister, downright pruderyl I am not for making mysteries of what all the world knows.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And how do I make mysteries pray?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Why, you confident thing! I'll prove it against you.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: But what? what? what will you prove?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: That you are ready to jump out of your little wits for a husband, my demure, sober sister. Miss Neville, a poet is not more eager for the success of a new comedy, nor one of his brother poets more desirous to see it fail, than that girl is to throw herself into the arms of a man.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: All scandal, sister.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Miss Neville shall be judge.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Your story is mere invention.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Was there ever such a wrangler?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You'll not make good your words.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, Miss, will you?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Very well, go on.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Will you have done? Now mind, Miss Neville. She does not want to be married, she says. The other night, my young Madam, whose thoughts are always composed and even, went to sleep as soon as we got to bed, and then her busy imagination went to work with all the vivacity of an intriguing chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And how can you tell that, pray?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Out of your own mouth you shall be judged. Miss Neville, she talked in her sleep, like a beauty in a side box, and then fell a singing,

l.hi: No, no; he is true, and I believe;
He look'd, he sigb'd, he can't deceive;
No, no; I have conquer'd; he is mine;
My heart is touch'd, and I resign.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Oh! you scurrilous creature.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Fairly caught, Lady Jane.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: All odious slander; you judge of me by yourself.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I do so. I mean to be married, and am frank enough to own it. But you may let "concealment feed on your damask cheek." My damask cheek, I hope, was made for other purposes.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Gracious! there is no bearing this. What a mad girl you are!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Not in the least. A natural character. One would not, to be sure, tell a hideous man that one loves him: but when one has encouraged him by degrees, and drawn him on, like a new glove, and perhaps done him a mischief in the doing it, why then one would draw him off again, and may be ask a pretty fellow to help a body; and then the wretch looks so piteous, and kneels at your feet, then rises in a jealous fit. I take my everlasting farewell; never to return; no, never; what to her? who encouraged me? encouraged him? who promised? broke her promise? The treacherous, faithless, dear deluding—then returns in an instant; hands dangling; eyes imploring; tongue faultering; Lady Bell, —Lady Bell—when you know that I adore you—And I burst into a fit of laughter in his face: Oh! that's my joy, my triumph, my supreme delight.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And is not there a kind of cruelty in all this?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! your very humble servant, my sweet Lady Graveairs. Cruelty! The difference between you and me, sister, is this; you deny your love to your female friends, and own it to the man; now I deny it to him, but among ourselves, I fairly own that Miss Neville is not more impatient to be married to Sir Harry, than I to—

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Who, I? Spare me, I beg of you. Why Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Now, now, your turn is come. Never spare her, sister?

sp.speaker: Mss NEV.
sp.p: You must excuse me, I am not in spirits for all this raillery.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You shan't leave us.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Give me leave; I beg you will. I'll go and talk to Madam La Rouge. Perhaps I may succeed for you.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Well, if you must go.—How you run on, sister! And are you really in love?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Over head and ears.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Not with Capt. Bygrove: how alarmed you are! With Millamour, sister.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Fix that roving temper, if you can; he will be on his knees to you, and the first pair of black eyes that enters the room will be through his heart.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: As to that, I give myself very little trouble: but if I could once catch him paying his adoration to me, my aunt Bromley does not raise and sink poor Miss Neville's spirits with such exquisite skill in the art of tormenting, as I should his. I should use him as the men do their punch; a little more sweet; a little more sower; a little more spirit; more acid again; then perhaps say it's good for nothing, and then, perhaps—

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Sip it up at last, as you would do at first. You wicked girl, how could you ask me such a question? Law! what am I about? I have a thousand things to do.

div3.stage: Enter Miss NEVILLE, and Madam LA ROUGE.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Ah! my Lady! always so gay; English climate no effect upon you. De maniere de Paris for all de vorl. En verite, vous est charmante.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p:
Oh! Madam La Rouge, you say such polite things; but you rob me of all my money.
My sister is rich: you had better deal with her. Sister, you'll be married before me.

div3.stage: "No, no, he is true, and I believe, &c.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Was ever any thing so crazy?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: It is all vivacite! and, my Lady, you have ver great wit en partage; vous avez les graces! you have de grace; but you no deal vid me.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: I shall call at your house in Pall mall. Miss Neville, you joined against me: I am very angry with you.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Madamoiselle, I tell you; persuade my Lady to have de lace, and you come to my house, me give you ver pretty present.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Oh! you have a national talent for applying a little bribery.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Diantre; 'tis false delicatesse. You not know de manieres of the vorl.—Ah! Monsieur Malvil!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Madam La Rouge. I did not expect this pleasure.

sp.speaker: La ROUGE.
sp.p: It is always pleasure to see mes amis; to see my friends; and I glad to see you here vid de Lady. You have ver good choice. And I can tell you, make dispatch: you have rival.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Rival?

sp.speaker: La ROUGE.
sp.p: You not know? Sir Harry have taske as well as you. Madamoiselle, you are ver great favourite.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: A favourite! keep your vivacity for some other subject: don't make me the town talk.

sp.speaker: La ROUGE.
sp.p: It is ver true: He come to my house in Pall-mall, and say ver fine ting of Madamoiselle Neville, and Monsieur Dash would praise you ver much.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Ay, his malice is at work.

sp.speaker: La ROUGE.
sp.p: Monsieur, you lose all your time— (goes to him and speaks low) You wait de fortune from Madam Bromley: Sir Harry vil take her vidout any money at all. Vat you slow for?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Are the apartments kept ready at your house?

sp.speaker: La ROU.
sp.p: De apartment it is ready. You take it two, tree week ago, and pay de rent for noting— I leave you vid de lady; and I go mind mes affaires. Bon voyage.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I have disengaged myself, to have the honour of attending you.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Your attention is thrown away. Did not I hear Mr. Millamour's voice?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Yes; he came with me; he is gone into the next room to pay his compliments to Lady Jane. I am sorry to see him for ever distracted; always resolving, and yet every day beginning the world over again. You look chagrin'd, what has disturb'd you?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: The old story; Mrs. Bromley's eternal whims.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: She is not spoken of as I could wish. Good natured and arrogant, generous and cruel, obliging and oppressive, at the same time.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: There cannot surely, be a more distressful situation than to remain under daily obligations, and yet not be able to esteem our benefactress.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Your delicacy charms me: It has fixed me yours. I long for nothing so much, as to see you out of her power. They have a strange report about town: people will be talking: the whisper goes that Mr. Bygrove, amidst all his grief, is slily in a hurry for another wife. Mrs. Bromley, they say, encourages him; and at the same time has a design upon my friend Millamour.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: The world is not always wrong.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Malice will be busy; and does not spare the young ladies.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: If any thing is said to their disadvantage, believe me, they do not deserve it.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I dare say not: I don't think they are too forward. I am sorry to see, in one of the papers to-day, a character of Sir Harry, not at all favourable. His little follies, his whims, and caprices one does not mind: He may walk in Dashwould's train as long as he pleases; that only makes him ridiculous. But it grieves me to hear that perfidy stains his character, and, as I am told, the worst of perfidy: the ruin of beauty and innocence is his ruling passion.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: This is very odd: somebody has been at the trouble of sending me an anonymous letter to that very effect: and why to me? I am not able to decypher.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I don't like anonymous letters. In general they aim at mischief, but this perhaps, is meant as a caution to you: it must be a friend that sent it.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: No; I can guess the quiver from whence that arrow comes.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Dashwould, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I don't say that.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Nor I; I never-charge any body; but upon recollection, the letter in the news-paper is imputed to him. Mrs. Bromley, I know, has no opinion of Sir Harry. His designs, with regard to you, she does not think honourable. My heart interests me for you. You know I am all heart. The plan which Mrs. Bromley has proposed—Hark! I think I hear Millamour coming. I'll follow you up stairs.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Oh! Sir! you have frighten'd me out of my wits.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p:
She loves Sir Harry, I see; and yet she shan't slip thro' my hands. I can set on Mrs. Bromley
to lead her a weary life, and if I can prevail upon Millamour to renounce Lady Bell, and marry the widow, my business is done. When Miss Neville is heartily tormented by Mrs. Bromley, affliction softens the mind, and I may then decoy her away, and stand upon terms with the family. But Dashwould's wit will fly about. No matter: he is a sad scoundrel, and does not mind how he murders reputations. So! here comes Millamour. I must get clear of him, and talk further with Miss Neville.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: From this moment I blot all other woman from my memory. malvil, wish me joy. The perplexity of choice is now at an end.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Why, what has happen'd?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lovely Lady Jane. "And yield her charms of mind with sweet delay."—I can't stay to tell you now.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Nor will I stay to interrupt your raptures. You know, I wish you success.

l.hi: Who yields too soon, must soon her lover lose:
Would you restrain him long? then long refuse.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: There is something commanding in that air of vivacity.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: "Oft at your door let him for entrance wait, There let him"— How! Millamour here! how could you surprize me so? You horrid thing! how long have you been here?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Been, Madam?—I have been—I have been in the next room, paying my respects to your sister.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And never enquired for poor Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Your Ladyship wrongs me. You doinjustice to your own charms: they can never beforgot.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I see how it is: the other day you was listed in my service, and now a deserter to my sister! you are right, you would have been upon hard duty with me.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Any duty but a forlorn hope would be—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Hope!—why sure, you would not have had the intolerable assurance, to entertain the smallest degree of hope? My sister, I suppose, has given you some hope. Ay! that's her way: She moves by settled rules, and shines with equal light. Now I—I am a mere comet, I blaze of a sudden; dazzle for a while, then wheel away, and am thought of no more.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: That gaiety of her's is charming, (aside) The impression your ladyship makes—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Words; mere words;—No; I am a strange piece of wild nature; never the same for two minutes together. Now, my sister, she is a Prussian blue, holds her colour, and is always the same.—I—I am a mere changeable silk—I shift about, and display my wit, and my folly, so curiously blended, that no body can tell where one begins, or the other ends. I am not worth your notice.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She has described herself admirably; without variety, a woman is a downright piece of insipidity.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Yes; I have my whims. Never the same for two minutes together. Now I love to give a scope to folly, and the men say, "curse catch her, she pleases more, when in the wrong, than other women when they are in the right. Then good sense is the word; and the next moment I can't bear the fatigue of thinking; why won't somebody write a comedy to divert me? Then all spirit, and I long to lead up the ball.

l.hi: Ladies, like variegated tulips, show
'Tis to their weakness all their charms they owe.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lade Jane is mere mediocrity compared to her.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Lord! I run on at a strange rate. Yours, Mr. Millamour: Au revoir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: A moment longer: you must not leave me: You possess my heart: possess it without a rival.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Hey! what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Do not trifle with a passion sincere as mine. I adore you, my Lady Bell; adore your matchless charms; thus on my knees adore.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Stay, stay; let me see what the poet says,

l.hi: Oft at your door let him for entrance wait,
There let him kneel, and threaten and entreat.

sp.p: There, stay there; don't offer to stir. Now put up both your hands, and pray, pray, have compassion, Lady Bell.

sp.speaker: MILLAMOUR.
sp.l: She flies disdainful from her lover's view,
Yet looks and bids him, as she flies, pursue.

div3.head: ACT the THIRD.
div3.stage: Enter Lady JANE, and Capt. BYGROVE.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: AND laid his commands upon you to address my sister?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Most peremptorily.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You have obeyed him I hope.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p:
You know your power too well; you
know that I am devoted to you, and that my happiness depends upon the promise you have made me.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: There, that is always the way with you men: our smiles, are sure marks of approbation; and every civil thing we say, is construed into a promise.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: And have not you promised?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Need I answer that question? How easily frightened you are! but you have some reason to be alarmed. Millamour has been on his knees to me, breathing such raptures—

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Ay!—who has set him on?—what can be at the bottom of this?—And have you listened to him?—Here comes Dashwould; he perhaps can explain.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: He will only laugh at us; and so I'll make my escape.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Not to hear Millamour again, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Well, well to purchase my liberty, you need not fear. I have received his vows, delivered with such ardour!—how terrified you look?—I have listened to him, to alarm my sister with an idea of Millamour's growing passion for me. If her jealousy is once touched, it may fix her resolution. At present, she is as volatile as Millamour himself.

sp.speaker: DASHW.
sp.p: As volatile as Millamour! what can that be? I never knew any thing that would bear a comparison

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: What think you of my sister?

sp.speaker: DASHW.
sp.p:
Lady Bell has her whims. I left her above stairs, in close conference with Millamour; he has deserted your Ladyship already. Mrs. Bromley will be the next, I hope: your father, would Captain,
would grieve more for that, than for his deceased wife.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And then Miss Nevill's turn may come.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Oh! no. To sport with her would be inhumanity. But a brisk widow, is fair game.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Yes, and it may help to cure my father of his folly.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: It would be sport, but I despair of it. You know, Mr. Dashwould, you allow that Millamour has understanding.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: But he does not act from his understanding. Fits and starts of passion govern him. If in any one pursuit of real use, he had half the alacrity of mind, with which he runs on, from one folly to another, he would be a man for the ladies to pull caps for. But he lives for ever in inconsistencies. One action of his life is the sure forerunner of the contrary. First Malvil is his favourite! then arm in arm with me: Can any two things be more opposite? It is the same among the ladies! they all have him by turns, and the whim of one moment, is sure to find a ridiculous antithesis in the next.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: He sat for that picture, I'll swear.— Well, there's a gentleman wants your advice, and so I'll leave you together.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: My dear Dashwould, you must assist me.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: What distresses you?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: My evil genius is at work. You know what my father has resolved upon. Lady Bell is the person he chuses for me.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I know all that business: a counterplot of the widow's fertile brain, to disappoint Lady Bell, and wreak her malice on Millamour.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p:
But the malice falls on me only. Why will not Millamour know his own mind? Lady Bell
loves him; I know she does. I am thwarted in the tenderest point; what must be done?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Do as they would have you: you ensure success. Millamour's jealousy takes fire upon the first alarm, and while the passion holds, he will have vigour enough to act decisively.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: May I hazard the Experiment?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: It's a sure card. Take my advice.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley's coach has just stopp'd at the door: had not you better step up stairs, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Dashwould, you are absent too long. They are all as dull as a funeral, above stairs.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: How the Baronet follows Miss Neville from room to room!—Come, Captain, I'll play a game of picquet with you before dinner.—Allons!

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: If I might have the liberty, ma'am, to—

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Another time, if you please, Sir Harry. Mrs. Bromley is coming: I hear her voice.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: And you promise me the hearing?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: You are entitled to it, Sir. I beg you'll leave me now.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: I obey your commands; I am gone; you'll remember.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Here she comes; and I think in good humour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p:
Oh! I am heartily tired. I have been paying visits to people who have never been let
into my house, and who, I hope, will never be at home for me. I hate them all, but out of civility, we must keep up an acquaintance. Where are the girls? Has any body been here?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Mr. Millamour, ma'am, and the rest of the gentlemen that dine here: they are all above stairs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Stupidity! did not I give orders— How long has Millamour been here?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: About an hour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: With Lady Bell, I suppose— Thou base ingratitude! and Sir Harry is here too, I reckon. Does your match go on? You shall go back to the country, I promise you. You'll be the ruin of those girls. They shall have no visitors, when my back is turned. I'll give orders to all the servants this very moment.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: To see Mrs. Bromley looking so well—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You are very polite, Sir. Business calls me now, Sir John; I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Has my son been here to-day?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: He is above stairs with Lady Bell, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Miss Neville, Neville, I say.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: You'll excuse me, Sir John; what can she want?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: This visit portends some good, I hope. I shall be happy if he has declared himself. I'll step and see what he is about.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Exquisite! lovely angel!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Well!—how!—what!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Sir; I am not at leisure; I am in the third region; and can't descend to the language of the nether world.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Then you are in love, George.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She is a sister of the Graces, and surpasses the other three. I am fixed; unalterably fixed; and am going about the marriage articles directly.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: They are at my lawyer's, ready engrossed; and only wait for the lady's name, to fill up the blanks.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I know it, Sir; I must step for them; I have it through my heart: I feel it here: I am your humble servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, no, do you stay here; I'll step for Mr. Copyhold. The writings shall be here in ten minutes.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: The sooner the better, Sir.

l.hi: Let those love now, who never lov'd before;
Let those who always lov'd, now love the more.

sp.p: Loll, tol, lol.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Bravo! you seem in prodigious spirits.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I am so: I am happy in myself, and happy in my friends, and happy in every circumstance, and in tip-top spirits, and—my dear Malvil, your's down to the ground.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Methinks I sympathize with you. When our friends are happy, the sensation is well called a fellow feeling.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p:
Malvil, I thank you: your turn of mind is formed for lasting friendships. With Dashwould it is all dissipation, and giddy mirth, the mere bubble of pleasure. To you, I may talk seriously, The topic of the day is enough for Dashwould. I can now tell you, that I shall be happy for life. But
for Dashwould, I should have been settled long ago. That fellow has led me into a thousand errors.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: He has his admirers, and not without reason. He thinks me his enemy, but he is mistaken. I never harbour resentment.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You are growing grave, and I am a flight above common sense at present.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Dashwould, notwithstanding all his faults, does hit the mark sometimes. I don't usually laugh at his pleasantry; I don't like to encourage him too much; but it must be owned, he is often right. Behind his back I cannot help being diverted by him. He has a quick insight into characters.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: No want of penetration there.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: No, no; he says, and perhaps rightly, your lively ladies often want common prudence; and giddy in the pursuit of pleasure, they are frequently miserable in the end.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: But Lady Bell's good sense, that refinement of understanding—

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: There are false refinements; the shadow for the substance. Who is it that observes, we all discover early symptoms of the disease, by which our minds and bodies go to ruin?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Po! with Lady Bell there can be no risk.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I don't know whether Dashwould is good authority.—You know him best. He says—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: He is a shrewd observer.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Nobody more so.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: If he has a regard for any body, it is for you. You are the only man I never heard him speak ill of. A match with Lady Bell is not to his mind. He talk'd seriously on the subject. Has not he told you?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Not a syllable.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I wonder at that. Lady Bell, he says, shew'd herself early. Impatient of advice, attentive to nothing but her beauty! whole days at her looking glass—I repeat his very words—he seemed to speak out of downright regard for you.—At her toilette every feature had its instructions how to look; but no instruction for the mind. And then, says he, that terrible love of gaming!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Gaming!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Don't you know it? I can't say I ever saw it myself. Time will determine her character.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: If she loves gaming, it is pretty well determined already.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Perhaps not: I still hope for the best.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Why yes; a man of sense may form her mind, and then the gentler affections may take their turn.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: The very thing I said.—But our pleasant friend had an answer ready—Gentle affections, says he! don't you see that it is with people that once love play, as with persons addicted to strong cordials? they never return to cooler liquors.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Thereis some truth in that. I am for ever obliged to you. It is ingenuous, it is friendly in you to convey the hint.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Don't build too much upon it. I have told you my author; and you know his way: he may deny it all.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Shall I talk to him?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I don't know what to say to that. In his vein of pleasantry, he may give it another turn.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: He may so. I am glad to know all this. But my Lady Jane, there's a model for her sex to imitate.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p:
Have you watch'd her well? People should appear what they really are. Let a precipice look like a precipice. When covered over with flowers,
it only serves to deceive the unwary. Mrs. Bromley has been very communicative about Lady Jane.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You alarm me. My dear friend explain.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: To do Lady Bell justice, she is above disguise. And though she has her faults, I have seen her please by those very faults.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And so have I. Her very blemishes are beauty spots.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: No frankness about the youngest girl. It is friendship for you that makes me speak. Her character is all forced, studied, put on with her rouge.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Does she paint?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: A little; the prudent touch. I am sorry for her. When she is settled in the world, many qualities, which now lie concealed, will break out into open day-light.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: What a masked battery there will be to play off upon her husband!

sp.speaker: MAL.
