sp.p: Their aunt told me all in confidence. You may judge how painful it is to her. I have known the family for some time. I can't but be sorry for the young ladies.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And since this is the case, I don't care how little I know of them, or their family.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: No occasion to quarrel with the family. Great merit about Mrs. Bromley. She made an admirable wife, and that at an early period. She was but seventeen when she married.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: No more?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Not an hour: she is not thirty: an estate in her own right, and the command of half a borough. No opposition there; the old houses have the votes. A man may get a seat without trouble. Does not Sir John want to see you in parliament?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes. It would give him pleasure.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Well, you will judge for yourself. Were I as you, I should know what course to take. Here she comes! a good fine woman! a man may there sit down to his happiness at once.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Mr. Millamour, (curtsies) Mr. Malvil, what have you done with Mr. Bygrove?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I parted with him where you set us down. (speaks to ber aside) I have talked to Millamour, and I think it will do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Go you up stairs.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: How charmingly you look! like Lady Bell's eldest Sister!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Po! you are laughing at me.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Not I truly: I appeal to Millamour. I'll take the liberty to join the company above. (aside to Millamour) She is the best of the family.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: A valuable man Mr. Malvil is! He has a great esteem for you, Sir. His sincerity is unequall'd. You seem thoughtful, Mr. Millamour.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Thoughtful, Ma'am!—There are certain subjects that—what Malvil says is true—A man may marry her, and sit down to his happiness at once

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Sir John has been saying a great deal to me about you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Has he, Ma'am!—There is a circumstance, which he is as yet a stranger to—a circumstance, which to communicate, will perhaps—It is what I have long wished, and—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Faultering! hesitating! (aside) I interrupt you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: There is a circumstance, Ma'am—the affair is—My father for a long time—Sir John, for a long time—Sir John has wished—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: To see you married?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: To see me married, Ma'am—and—he has —he has wished it much.—And a settlement, by way of jointure—long ready for the lady's name—that is—any lady, who shall honour me with her affection —and—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: No lady can be insensible of your pretensions.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You are very good, Ma'am; and after long observation, and a lasting passion grafted on it, which, tho' silent hitherto, —yet working secretly—when disclosed at length—may to the person in the world— who already formed by experience, may in every respect —and if without presuming too far—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: What a delicate confusion he is in.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And if this paper, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: When given by you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Perverse and cruel!

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: You both look grave; nothing amiss, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Every thing is as it should be, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Not if he knew all.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Sir John has been complaining—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Pass that by; advise your own son; had not you better step up stairs? Mr. Millamour will do what is right. (siniling at him) You may leave it all to him; trust to his judgment.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Millamour, I have such a story for you: Malvil and Dashwould have been quarrelling about you, and—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Po! and here they all come; I knew the substance could not be far off, when the shadow projected before it.

div3.stage: Enter Lady BELL, DASHWOULD, and MALVIL.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Mr. Dashwould, do you think I'll bear this? What liberty will you take next? You think, because I laugh, that I am not offended.— Aunt, I received a letter, and he has attempted to snatch it from me.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Why it brings a little cargo of ridicule from the country, and my friend Malvil sees no joke in it.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: When my friend's name is brought in question, Sir—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: It is diverting notwithstanding.— Aunt, what do you think? My Cousin Cynthia, you know, was to be married to Sir George Squanderstock; her mother opposed it, and broke off the match, and now it's come out, that she was all the time the clandestine rival of her own daughter.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Not inapplicable to the present business.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Go, you giddy girl, no such thing!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She charms by her very faults.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: And Dashwould has been saying—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Po! repeat none of his sayings to me.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Did you say any thing, Mr. Dashwould? What was it?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Oh! nothing. Sir George Squanderstock is my very good friend.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: And for that reason you might spare him No man is without his faults.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Ay, allow him faults, out of tenderness.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Sir George is a valuable man, Sir, and represents his county to great advantage.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He does so; takes a world of pains; nothing can escape him; Manilla ransom not paid; there must be a motion about that matter: he knots his handkerchief to remember it.—Scarcity of corn! another knot—triennial parliaments— (knots) Juries Judges of law as well as fact (knots) national debt (knots) bail in criminal cases (knots) and so on he goes, till his handkerchief is twisted into questions of state; the liberties and fortunes of all posterity dangling like a bede roll; he puts it in his pocket, drives to the gaming table, and the next morning his handkerchief goes to the wash, and his country and the minority are both left in the suds.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: What a description!

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Hey! lively Lady Bell!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Ho! ho! I thank you, Dashwould.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: How can you encourage him? Let us leave 'em to themselves.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: You see, Mr. Bygrove—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Ay! thus he gets a story to graft his malice upon, and then he sets the table in a roar at the next tavern.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Never be out of humour with Dashwould, Mr. Bygrove; he keeps me alive; he has been exhibiting pictures of this sort all the morning, as we rambled about the town.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Oh! no; no pictures; I have shewn him real life.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Very true, Dashwould: and now mind him: he will touch them off to the life for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Millamour so close with Lady Bell! the forward importunity of that girl.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p:
There is positively no such thing as going about this town, without seeing enough to split your
sides with laughing. We called upon my friend Sir Volatile Vainlove: he, you know, shines in all polite assemblies, and is, if you believe himself, of the first character for intrigue. We found him drinking Valerian tea for his breakfast, and putting on false calves.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: And the confusion he was in, when we entered the room!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: In the next street, we found Jack Spinbrain, a celebrated poet, with a kept mistress at his elbow, writing lampoons for the news-paper; one moment murdering the reputation of his neighbours, and the next a suicide of his own.—We saw a young heir, not yet of age, granting annuity bonds, and five Jews and three Christians, duped by their avarice to lend money upon them. A lawyer—

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Hear, hear; it is all true. I was with him.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: A lawyer taking notes upon Shakespeare: a deaf Nabob ravished with music, and a blind one buying pictures. Men without talents, rising to preferment, and real genius going to a jail.—An officer in a marching regiment with a black eye, and a French hair-dresser wounded in the sword arm.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! by this light I can vouch for every word.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Go on, Sir Harry, ape your friend in all his follies; be the nimble marmozet; grin at his tricks, and try to play them over again yourself.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Well now, that is too severe: Dashwould, defend me from his wit. You know I hoard up all your good things.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You never pay me in my own coin, Sir Harry: try now; who knows but you will say something?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Friend or foe it is all alike.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And where is the mighty harm? I like pulling to pieces of all things.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p:
To be sure it is the
life of conversation. Does your Ladyship know Sir George Squanderstock's sister?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I have seen her.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She is a politician in petticoats; a fierce republican; she talks of the dagger of Brutus, while she settles a pin in her tucker; and says more about ship money, than pin-money.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And now you must turn bussoon?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I know the lady; she scolds at the loyalists, gossips against the act of settlement, and has the fidgets for magna charta.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She encourages a wrinkle against bribery; flirts her fan at the ministry, and bites her lips at taxes, and a standing army.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mr. BYCROVE, will you bear all this?

div3.stage: Enter Miss NEVILLE, and whispers Mrs. BROMLEY.

sp.speaker: Mrs Brom.
sp.p: Very well, Neville, I'll come presently.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I shall stay no longer. Mr. Bygrove, will you walk?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No, Sir, I shall not leave the enemy in this room behind me: a bad translator of an antient poet, is not so sure to deface his original, as his licentious strain to disparage every character.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Sir Harry, he will neither give, nor take a joke.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: No, I told you so.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Let me tell you once for all, Sir—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I wish you would.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Why interrupt? Do you know what I was going to say?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: No, do you?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I'll leave 'em all to themselves.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Millamour gone!

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p:
Let me tell you, Sir, with all your flashes of wit, you will find that you have been playing with an edge-tool at last. And what does this mighty witamount
to? The wit in vogue, exposes one man; makes another expose himself; gets into the secrets of an intimate acquaintance, and publishes a story to the world; belies a friend; puts an anecdote, a letter, an epigram into the news-paper; and that is the whole amount of modern wit.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: A strain of morose invective is more diverting, to be sure.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Well, Sir, we'll adjourn the debate. You may go on; misrepresent every thing; if there is nothing ridiculous, invent a story: and when you have done it, it is but a cheap and a frivolous talent. Has a lady a good natural bloom? Her paint must be an expensive article. Does she look grave? She will sin the deeper. Is she gay and affable? Her true character will come out at the Commons. That is the whole of your art, and I leave you to the practice of it.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Satyrical Bygrove! now the widow has him in tow.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Could not you stay till my back was fairly turned?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: What a look there was!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: At what a rate you run on! you keep the field against them all.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Sir Harry, step up, and watch him with the widow.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I will; don't stay too long.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I'll follow you: and hark, make your party good with Miss Neville.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: You see, Lady Belt, a sling at every body.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The Baronet does not want parts; that is to say, he has very good materials to play the fool with. I shall get him to marry Miss Neville.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Bring that about, and you will for once do a serious action, for which every body will honour you.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: In the mean time, do you watch your aunt Bromley: she is your rival.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Rival? That would be charming!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: It is even so. Now Millamour's understanding is good, but his passions quick: if you play your cards right—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Are you going to teach me how to manage a man?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Coquettry will never succeed with him. A quicksand does not shift so often as his temper. You must take him at his word, and never give him time to change, and veer about.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Totally out of nature.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Oh! very well. I give up the point.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: You may leave the man to my management. My aunt Bromley rival me! that would be delightful.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Well, sister!

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Can you be serious for a moment?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Well, the solemnity of that look! Must I set my face by yours, and contract a wrinkle, by a formal oeconomy of features, which you, like the rest of the world, mistake for wisdom?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Will you hear me? They are hurrying this match too fast, I think. Sir John is come, and his lawyer is expected every moment. He wants to conclude the affair this day, and my aunt does not oppose it. But I don't like all this hurry.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And why need you be concerned about it?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Do you think Millamour capable of love?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: For the moment. It will be difficult to fix him.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Do?—Nothing.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE,
sp.p: How silly! you know it is not my seeking.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: What are you about? Talking in your sleep again? Lady Jane, wake yourself. What have you taken into your head?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Why since Mr. Millamour has prevailed with me—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: His affections then are fixed upon you?—Why the man has been dying at my feet, with a face as rueful as a love elegy.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You will permit me to laugh in my turn.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! I can laugh with you, and at you, and at him too. This gives spirit to the business: here are difficulties, and difficulties enhance victory, and victory is triumph.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Very well! oh! brave! laugh away! you will be undeceived presently.—If this does not take, I am at the end of my line.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: What does all this mean? Rivall'd, outwitted by my sister! Insupportable! This begins to grow serious.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! she here! Sir John is quite impatient, and I am going for his attorney.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And Lady Jane is impatient too: she is the object of your choice.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lady Jane! you are pleasant, very pleasant!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: She has told me with inflexible gravity!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She is a great wit; and great wits have great quickness of invention; and so a story is easily dressed up. I could crack my sides with laughing. If trifling civilities have been received as a declaration of love—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And is that the case? Very whimsical indeed!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes, very whimsical! I am eternally yours, ma'am, and I am on the wing, and your Ladyship's adorer.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Now to plague 'em both.— Sister, you may hear it from himself.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Confusion!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: That lady, Sir, has the strangest notion.—

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You will be so good as to explain all to my sister.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Both upon me at once.—I have explained, madam, and all further talk about it is unnecessary.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Only to satisfy her curiosity.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: To shew my sister her mistake.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I have made every thing clear, ma'am.— (to Lady Bell) Have not I, Lady Bell? And— (turns to Lady Jane) every thing now is upon a proper footing.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Very well; only give her to understand—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Your understanding is admirable. (turns to Lady Bell) I told you she would talk in this style. (turns to Lady Jane) You are perfectly right, and nobody understands things better. (turns to Lady Bell) Nobody whatever.
sp.stage: (looks and laughs at both by turns)

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: But give me leave. You must speak out, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Never argue about it, it is not worth your while.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: There is some mystery in all this.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: No; all very clear: (to Lady Jane) drop it for the present.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: But I desire no doubt may remain.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And I don't like to be kept in suspense.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Distraction! I am like a lawyer, that has taken fees on both sides. You do me honour, ladies; but upon my soul, I can't help laughing. It will divert us some day or other, this will. Oh! ho! ho! I shall die with laughing.

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. BROMLEY, and Sir JOHN.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: What is all this uproar for?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Another witness of my folly!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Millamour, I give you joy: Mr. Copyhold, your attorney, is come with the deeds. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: The strangest adventure! I can't stay now. The ladies have been very pleasant. You love humour, and they have an infinite deal. I'll come to you in a moment.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: George, don't run away: let us finish the business.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: If he says he'll marry, you may depend upon him. A poet, determined to write no more, or a gamester forswearing play, is not so sure to keep his word. I wish I may die, if I don't think him as much to be relied upon as a prime minister.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Aunt? Would you believe it? The demure Lady Jane— (bursts into a laugh) She has taken such a fancy into her head! Millamour she thinks is up to the eyes in love with her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! poor Lady Jane!

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And my sister's pride is hurt. She carries it with an air, as if she had made a complete conquest.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: How ridiculous the girls are! your son has open'd his mind to you, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He has, and I approve of his choice. I hope it is as agreeable to you, as to his father.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I don't know how to refuse my consent.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: What does all this mean?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: As I could wish, There he is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Since it has your approbation, Sir John, I believe I must yield my consent. I never thought to marry again, but since you will have it so—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Lady Bell I understand, is willing to do me the honour of being my daughter in law.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! ho! this makes amends for all. My dear Aunt Bromley, are you imposed upon? Did you listen to the traitor's vows?— The dear, perfidious?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He will soon be settled, Sir John, since there are now three rival goddesses contending for him. Mr. Bygrove, you are come in good time.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: What fool's part are you to play now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Sir John, I desire I may not be made your sport. Have not I here, under his hand, a declaration of his mind; here, in this copy of verses, given to me by himself, an earnest of his affection?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Verses! Aunt?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Verses to you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Verses to me: only hear, Sir John.

l.hi: "I look'd, and I sigh'd, and I wish'd I could speak,"
"And sain would have paid adoration.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Stay, stay; mine begin the same way:

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: The very words of mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Will those girls have done?

p.hi: "But when I endeavour'd the matter to break,"
"Still then I said least of my passion."

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Will you be quiet?

l.hi: "Still then I said least of my passion;"

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: "And resolv'd I would try.

p.hi: "Some way my poor heart to recover."

sp.speaker: Lady JANE, Lady BELL, and Mrs. BROMLEY.

l.hi: "But that was all vain, for I sooner could die,
"Than live with forbearing to love her.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! ho! Mr. Dashwould, what a piece of work has he made?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And the verses copied from Congreve.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Copied from Congreve!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: There, Sir John, there is your son's behaviour!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: There, Mr. Bygrove, there is the widow's behaviour.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And now, Mr. Dashwould, now for your wit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROMLEY.
sp.p: I am not disappointed in the least, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I never was so cover'd with confusion!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I never was so diverted in all my days.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He has acted with great propriety upon the occasion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p:
He has made himself very ridiculous.
He has exposed nobody but himself. Contempt is the only passion he can excite. A crazy, mad, absurd—

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: An inconstant, wild, irresolute—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! so whimsical a character.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: This behaviour will give him prodigious lustre. He will shine after this. I hope his visits will cease at this house.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: If ever you marry again, similitude of temper must do it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Distraction! must you plague me too?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: You have appear'd with an air, but it was all struggling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I cannot bear this.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Heavens knows how you have struggled!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: And you too? (mimicks him) "A march in your family has diverted me of late." I renounce you all. Come, Lady Bell, Lady Jane, let us leave them to themselves.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You would not believe me, sister.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL
sp.p: Oh! this to me is as good as a comedy.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: What shall I give you for your chance?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: More than I'll give you for your wit. And there's your answer.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The old pike is hooked, and struggles still at the end of her line.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Mr. Dashwould, speak to this silly young man. You have influence over him. Keep him to dinner. You will for ever oblige me. I must go and pacify the ladies.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Poor Millamour! Dryden has painted him to a hair.
sp.l: Blest madman, who can every hour employ,
With something new to wish, or to enjoy.

div3.head: ACT the FOURTH.

sp.speaker: DASHWOULD.
sp.p: THIS way, Sir Harry. While they are all engaged in the pleasures of the table, I want a word with you in private.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: With that face of importance! what is coming now?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Listen to me: know a little of the subject before you give your opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: I am all attention.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Did you mark Miss Neville, at dinner?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: You know I did. And when Mrs. Bromley railed at her—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: She railed at her with a littleness of spirit, that disgraced wealth and affluence, and gave to poverty the superior character. You must have seen in the behaviour of that girl, though treated with pride and arrogance, a propriety that was elegant, and went even further; it interested every heart for her. She is the best of the group. Were I, at the head of such a fortune as yours, to choose a wife, she should be the object of my affection.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: You have some scheme in all this.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I have; to serve you. I should mortify the pride of Mrs. Bromley, by placing a valuable, but helpless, young lady upon a level with her at once.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: This is to end in some joke.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Wait for the wit before you laugh. I am in serious earnest. Her understanding is the best among them. The others are all artificial; she is a natural character; and if I am not mistaken, has a heart. If I wanted heirs to my estate, she should be the mother of my children.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Were I to be the dupe of all this, how you would laugh at me? Ha! ha! ha! I know you too well.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Again! laughing without the provocation of a joke. Don't be the dupe of your own cunning. I know you love her; and will it not be a generosity worthy of you, to extricate merit out of distress? Nay, the merit which you admire? The merit which would do honour to the choice of any man in England?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Well, I cannot contain.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: The scrape in which you involved Millamour with the widow!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Foolish! that was Malvil's doing. You'll hear more of it by and by. There is an underplot in all his actions. I advise you for the best. Here is a lady in question, untainted by the fashions of the age. Make her your own. She has no fortune; what then? Shew yourself superior to the sordid views, that govern the little mercenary spirits of the world.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: I have just recollected what you said of Jack Invoice, upon his marriage.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p:
Jack Invoice! He never was intended for any thing but to be laughed at. Upon the death of a rich uncle in the city, he comes to the west end of the town, with a plumb in his pocket, and not an idea in his head; marries a fantastical woman of rank, and with a sovereign contempt of all his former acquaintance, mixes with lords and people of quality,
who win his money, and throw his wig in the fire to divert themselves. He laughs at their wit, and thinks himself in good company.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Admirable! you have him to a hair.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Hey! the picture is like.— (laughs)—Pretty well, is not it?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! the very thing! poor Jack Invoice! you have hunted him down.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Have I? (laughs) Yes, I think I have been pleasant upon him. But come; to our point: in marrying Miss Neville, there is nothing ridiculous. You like her, that's clear.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: But she does not like me, and that's as clear. Somebody has done me a prejudice there. She received this letter, and gave it me to read.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: "To Miss Neville— (opens it) Without a name?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: A poison'd arrow in the dark.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Anonymous letters are generally the effect of clandestine malice; this comes from a friend. If your honour, your virtue, and your peace of mind, are worth your care, avoid the acquaintance of Sir Harry. He is the deceiver of innocence, and means to add your name to the list of those whom his treachery has already ruined. Make use of this hint, and act accordingly.—A pretty epistle— (pauses) Don't I know this hand?— So, so! I understand it: I can trace this: say no more, Sir Harry: pursue Miss Neville the closer for this. Will you let such a fellow as Malvil, rob you of a treasure?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: You don't suspect him?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Leave it all to me. Assure Miss Neville that this shall be cleared up. Hush! we are interrupted: go and join the company.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Pshaw! pox! the company without you—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Very well; leave me now: (Exit Sir Harry) What's the matter, Malvil?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: It will be over presently: a sudden sensation; I can't bear to see others made unhappy. Mrs. Bromley is a very valuable woman, but at times rather violent.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And that's much to be lamented, is not it?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: You may laugh at it, Sir, but I think it a serious matter. I left poor Miss Neville in a flood of tears; and—here she comes.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Not rising from table so soon?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Excuse me, Sir, I had rather not stay.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Never mind Mrs. Bromley's humours; come, we will all take your part.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I am not fit for company, Sir.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I am sorry to lose you: I'll leave you with my worthy friend; he will administer consolation.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Was there ever such inhuman tyranny? Insulted before the whole company!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: It hurts me to the quick. I could not have believed her capable of such violence.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: You saw that I gave her no provocation.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: It pains me to see what I do.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: She breaks out in such passionate onsets, and never considers that an overbearing pride is the worst of cruelty to an ingenuous mind.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p:
There are few who know how to confer an obligation. A disinterested action gives such moments of inward pleasure! Oh! there are moments of the heart, worth all the giddy pleasures of life.
One benevolent action pays so amply, and yields such exquisite interest, that I wonder people are not fond of laying out their money in that way.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: During the whole time of dinner, it was one continued invective against me.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Millamour's behaviour had disconcerted her. But that is no excuse. Goodness by fits, and generosity out of mere whim, can never constitute a valuable character. I am sorry to see you so afflicted.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: You are very good, Sir.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: No, I have no merit in it; the instincts of my nature leave me no choice. I have studied myself, and I find I am only good by instict. I am strangely interested for you. I have thought much of your situation: our time is short; they will be all rising from table, presently. Attend to what I say: since Mrs. Bromley is so incessant in her tyranny, do as I already hinted to you. Withdraw from this house at once. Madam la Rouge has an apartment ready for you. You may there remain concealed. In the mean time I shall be at work for you. I shall prevail upon Mrs. Bromley to keep her word, about the five thousand pounds. That added to what is in my power, will make a handsome settlement for you.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: You heard what she said to Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: She wants to drive you to some act of despair; perhaps to give you up a sacrifice to Sir Harry's loose desires.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Are you so clear about Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Sdeath! I see she loves him.—Hereafter I will open a scene to astonish you. (pauses, and looks at her) You can never be happy under this roof. Mrs. Bromley will make this quarrel up, I know she will. The whole of her virtue consists in repentance, but what kind of repentance? A specious promise to reform her conduct, and a certain return of the same vices.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: She has made me desperate. I can stay here no longer. I'll go back to the country. I shall there be at peace.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: You will be there too much out of the way. When you are settled at Madam La Rouge's, the haughty Mrs. Bromley will see to what she has driven you, and for the sake of her character, will begin to relent. Sir Harry must not know where you are. He means your ruin, I am sorry to say it, but I can give you such convincing proof.—

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: BROM. Do you go to your room, madam; let me see you no more to-day.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: It was a mere unguarded word that fell from Miss Neville. (speaks to Mrs. Bromley aside) Millamour is ashamed of his conduct, He is under my influence still: I shall mould him to your wishes.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: BROM. (aside to him) I am a fool to think any more about him. Go to him; watch him all day; you will not find me ungrateful. (loud) And pray tell those girls to come up stairs. (Exit Malvil) Mighty well, madam. (to Miss Neville) You must sit next to Sir Harry: You have pretensions, have you? And you must vouch for Lady Bell too? She does not love gaming; that story is all calumny: bespeak yourself a place in the stage coach; you shall quit this house, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: It will be the last time I shall receive those orders, madam. Your favours are so embittered; there is such a leaven of pride, even in your acts of bounty, that I cannot wish to be under any further obligations. If doing justice to Lady Bell, if avowing my sentiments in the cause of so amiable a friend, can give you umbrage, I am not fit to remain in this house.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: O brave! you shall travel. Give her a fortune! No, let Lady Bell reward her. How! —Millamour, as I live.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Deliver me, fate! she here:—Madam— I—I—I—you are not going to leave us, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mirs. BROM.
sp.p: And how can you look me in the face?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I am glad you are come, Sir, I wanted to—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Perverse! what brings Sir John? (aside)—I shall expect you above stairs, gentlemen. I must try once more to fix that irresolute, inconstant man.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What a day's work have you made here?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Can you expect any good from all this? Ever doing and undoing! These proceedings are terrible to your father.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You know, Sir, that to gratify you is the height of my ambition.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: For shame! don't imagine that you can deceive me any longer. Are you to be for ever in suspence? Always resolving, and yet never decided? Never knowing your own mind for five minutes?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I have not been hasty to determine.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My indulgence has made me too ridiculous. You will force me to tell you my mind in harsher terms than I ever thought I should have occasion to do.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: What has happened to-day, was but a mere frolic, and it has all passed off in a little raillery.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And do you think that sufficient? While you remain insensible of your folly; transferring your inclinations from one object to another; hurried away by every casualty, you will prove the jest of all your acquaintance. You will cease to live, before you have begun.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: This is rather too much, Sir. If I have, in a few instances, departed from a resolution that seemed fixed, you know very well, it is not uncommon; and when a person means an extraordinary leap, he retires back, to take advantage of the ground, and spring forward with greater vigour.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And thus you amuse yourself, compounding upon easy terms, for the folly of every hour. There is no relying upon you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: After all, Sir, it is the prudent part to consider every thing. The ladies were rather hasty in their conclusion. In our moments of reflection, as objects pass before us, opinion will wear different colours.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The very cameleon has that merit: but is there to be nothing inward? No self-governing principle? A ship without a pilot, without rudder, or compass, is as likely to avoid rocks, and quicksands, as you to steer clear of ruin.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You seem exasperated, but I really don't see the cause.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No?—Can't you feel how absurd it is to be always beginning the world? Forever in a doubt? Day after day embarking in new projects, nay twenty different projects in one day, and often in an hour?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Spare my confusion: I feel my folly; I feel it all; and let my future conduct.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: George, can I take your word? I know you have been at the gaming table.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: The gaming table !

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Say no more: I know it all: after the indulgence I have shewn you, I now see that my hopes are all to be disappointed. If you have a mind to attone for what is past, pursue one certain plan, and be somebody. The time now opens a new scene, and calls for other manners. Reform your conduct, and I shall be happy. But I am tired of this eternal levity: my patience is wore out. I shall stay no longer in this house to be a witness of your absurdity.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I have made myself very ridiculous here. I can't shew my face any more in this family. I'll go back to the Temple, and not marry these ten years. The law leads to great things: a seat in Parliament, a vote or two against your conscience, a silk gown, and a judge; that's the course of things. I'll pursue my ambition.—Honest friend, (calls to a servant) hist! honest friend, will you be so good as just to get my hat?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: No, I bar hats. What, going to desert us? The sport is but just beginning. Bygrove has been lecturing his son, and quarreling with Malvil. The integrity of that honest gentleman is suspected at last. He was the worthiest man in the world this morning, as good a creature as ever was born, but now he has sold himself to the widow. Lady Bell has been lively upon the occasion; and Malvil, to support his spirits, has plyed the Burgundy, till he looks the very picture of hypocrisy, with a ruddy complexion, and a sparkling eye.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You may divert yourself, Sir; I have done with them all.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p:
But I can't part with you: you shall join us; Malvil shall have no quarter: he will stick to
his glass till his charity for his neighbour begins to stagger; then off drops the mask: he will have courage enough to rail at mankind, and his true character will come forth, like letters in lemon juice before the fire.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Po! absurd! I am on the rack. Why did you force me to stay dinner? I have been so weak, so frivolous.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: How so? Because you chang'd your mind? There is nothing more natural. Don't you see men doing the same thing every day? Down goes the old mansion; a new one rises; exotic trees smile on the landscape, and enjoy the northern air; and when the whole is finished, in less than a twelve-month, the auctioneer mounts his pulpit. "Pleasing contiguity" —"Beautiful, and picturesque scene"—"Delectably featured by Nature"—"Shall I say twenty thousand?—Down it goes to the highest bidder, who pays his money, and runs away the next morning with an opera singer to Italy.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Why, yes, we see these things every day.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: No doubt; men are fickle, and inconstant

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Very true; it is the way through life; in the lowest rank, as well as the highest. You shan't see a journeyman Weaver, but he has his disgust, like a Lord, and changes his lodging, his house of call, his barber, and his field preacher.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Certainly; and then there is a real charm in variety. Besides what you did to day, was a mere frolic.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Nothing more: and that fellow, Malvil, was the occasion of it. My heart never rightly warmed to that man. I shall never consult him again. Affairs were in a right train, if he had not interposed.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p:
You shall have your revenge. I have a mine to spring will blow him up— (laughs) His advice
to-day has served to produce the widow's character.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes, it has given a display of her. (laughs) How could she think me in earnest? Marry her! I would go into the army sooner.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: A good pretty trade, the army: if you are killed in battle, it is your affair; if you conquer, you may retire, and live very prettily upon half pay.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Very true: the law is a more certain road.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: A good agreeable life the law is: for ever entangled in the cobwebs of Westminster-hall; and you help to spin them yourself into the bargin.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And at the end of twenty years, you are thought a good promising young man.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: In the mean time you are constantly hiring out your lungs, and ever in a passion about other people's affairs.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And travelling circuits, in hopes of finding each county distracted: with a barbarous, bloody murder, in every jail, and so live upon the calamities of mankind.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Like physicians, when a north-east wind, a Lord Mayor's feast, or a jail distemper, has made a good sickly time of it.

div3.stage: Enter Lady BELL, and Lady JANE.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Come, sister, leave the men to themselves. Mr. Dashwould, has their wit frightened you away?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: "Look in her face, and you forget them all."

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Won't your Ladyship have compassion on that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Compassion!—my sister and I, we hope for his protection?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: When you go away from company, Lady Bell, you draw every body in your train.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! you have so overpowered me with civil, and tender things!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: What does he follow her for?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: A l'honneur, gentleman. (goes up to Millamour) Uncle! Uncle Millamour, when you are married to my aunt, I hope you will be kind to us both.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Confusion! daggers! daggers!

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: May I salute you, uncle?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Po! this foolery!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Let us give him all his titles!—Brother —when you marry my Sister.—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: How can you, Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Uncle!—Brother!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And Brother Uncle!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: This is too much —No patience can endure it. (turns to Lady Bell) Madam, this usage— (Lady Bell and Lady Jane both laugh loud.)

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Come, sister, let us leave him.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! I shall expire.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Why will you torment me thus? (takes her by the hand) Am I to be for ever made your sport?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! you would not have me laugh. To be sure, when one considers, it is a serious matter. And though Captain Bygrove (pointing to him) has orders to be in love with me; and though he has declared himself in the warmest terms—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And could you listen to him?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And yet after all your promises, when you had touched my heart—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Jealous of me by this light.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: After all your faithless vows, to break them as you have done, like a Turk, or a Jew, or a Mahometan, (crying) and leave me, like Dido and Aeneas, it is enough to break a young girl's heart. (crying bitterly) so it is, it is—There, will that please you? (bursts into a laugh) Adieu, uncle! my compliments to my aunt—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Did not I hear somebody crying?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes, and laughing too. Captain Bygrove, you said something to Lady Bell, what was it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: What I desire the world to know; I love her, I adore her. My father has order'd it, Mrs. Bromley approves; Lady Bell encourages me; and I shall be the happiest of mankind.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You and I must talk apart, Sir. You know my prior claim. Attempt my life rather than my love. You must think no more of her, Sir; she is mine by every tie, and so I shall tell her this moment.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Now hold that resolution, if you can.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: I have managed it well.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Admirably!

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: What does all this mean? Dashwould, you are wanted in the next room. Malvil is in for it: he sits toasting Miss Neville, while every idea fades away from his countenance, all going out one by one, and his eye sinks into the dim vacuity of a brisk no meaning at all.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I'll look in upon them.—Bygrove, I see Miss Neville: let us give Sir Harry his opportunity.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I thought Lady Bell was here: I beg your pardon; gentlemen.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Your company is always agreeable, is not it, Sir Harry? The gentleman will speak for himself. Come, Bygrove, I have occasion for you.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: May I now presume, Madam—

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: You chuse your time but ill, Sir Harry. I have so many things to distract me, I cannot listen to you now.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: But you promised to hear me; I have long beheld your sufferings.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: They do not warrant improper liberties. I can be humble as becomes my situation. I hope you will not oblige me to shew that spirit, which virtue is as much intitled to, as the proudest fortune in the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: I mean you no disrespect. That letter is a black artifice to traduce my character: the fraud shall be brought to light; you may rely upon it; nor will you be so ungenerous as to believe the dark assassin of my honour.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I know not what foundation there is for it, nor is it for me to charge you with any thing. I have no right to take that liberty.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Why harbour suspicions unworthy of you? In me, you behold a warm admirer, who aspires at the possession of what he loves, and trembles for the event.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I must take the liberty to doubt your sincerity. I know my own deficiencies, and Ibeg leave to withdraw.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: By all that's amiable in your mind and person, my views are honourable as ever yet inspired alover's heart.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I would fain express my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Why those tears?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Your character, I dare say, Sir, will come out clear and unsullied. You will permit me to take care of mine. It is all I have to value. I shall not continue any longer in this house. Mrs. Bromley has made it impossible; I wish you all happiness, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: That resolution I approve of: let me provide you a retreat, and in a few days—

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I must beg to be excused: that I can never think of.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: By Heaven, I mean to raise you to that independance, which your merit deserves. I would place you in that splendor, which Mrs. Bromley may envy.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I can only return my thanks. Lady Bell will know where I am. I feel no ambition: I do not want to give pain to Mrs. Bromley: I seek humble content, and ask no more.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: You do injustice to yourself and to me: —Hey! all breaking up from table!

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: You must not detain me now, Sir Harry. I humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: I wonder what Dash wood will say to all this. I shall like to hear him: he will turn it to a joke, I warrant him. No end of his pleasantry.

div3.stage: Enter MALVIL in liquor, BYGROVE, and DASHWOULD.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Very well; make the most of it. Since you force me to speak, I say her character is a vile one.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Here is a fellow whom wine only inspires with malice.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Po! malice! Malvil has no harm in him.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: You may talk of Mrs. Bromley, but she is as vile a character, as pride, and insolence, and avarice, and vanity, and fashionable airs, and decayed beauty can jumble together.

sp.speaker: BYO.
sp.p: Here's a return for her hospitality!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Marry her, I say; marry her, and try.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: You shall not have a shilling with Miss Neville.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: There, the secret's out: you want to marry her, and make her break her word. Mankind's a villain! a medley of false friends, eloping wives, stock jobbers, and usurers; wits that won't write, and fools that will.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Dashwould, you are a panegyrist, compared to this man.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Yes, he takes your trade out of your hands.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: She is Mrs. Bromley, the widow, and you are Mr. Bygrove, the widower; and so, bite the biter, that's all.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: His wit soars above you, Mr. Dashwould.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Wit is a bad trade. Letters have no friend left in these degenerate times. Shew a man of letters to the first of your nobility, and they will leave him to starve in a garret. Introduce a fellow, who can sing a catch, write a dull political pamphlet, or remarks upon a Dutch memorial, or play off fireworks, and he shall pass six months in the country, by invitation. Maecenas died two thousand years ago, and you are not historian enough to know it.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Dashwould, he makes a bankrupt of you.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: I have found him out: I know him now: a pretended friend, that he may more surely betray you. Go, and get some coffee, to settle your head.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley will settle your head.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Let us take him up stairs; he'll tumble over the tea-table, to shew his politeness.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Come, the ladies wait for us.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mankind, I say, is a villain!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Bless me, Mr. Malvil!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: All Dashwould's doing to expose a body. Do you look to Millamour, that's what I say to you.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He shan't stay to plague your Ladyship.— Come, Malvil, let us go and be tender of reputation above stairs.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I'm always tender, and you are scurrilous.

div3.stage: sings, and Exit, led by Dashwould and Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: How Millamour follows me up and down! Charming! here he comes.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lady Bell, allow me but one serious moment.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: This bracelet is always coming off.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Whatever appearances may have been, I burn with as true a passion, as ever penetrated a faithful heart.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I know he is mine. —This silly, obstinate bauble! What were you saying? Oh! making love again.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: By this dear hand I swear—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Hold, hold, no violence. Give me my liberty, and thus I make use of it.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL,
sp.p: Oh! I have been wishing for you. How could you stay so long?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: They detained me against my will. But you see, I am true to my appointment.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Are you so? You shall keep an appointment with me.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I was surrounded with darts, and flames. That gentleman was for renewing the old story, but it is so ridiculous!
sp.stage: (walks up the stage with Capt. Bygrove)

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Distraction! to be insulted thus!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: You have prevailed upon me to be in earnest at last. Since your father has proposed it, and since you have declared yourself, why, if I must speak, get my aunt's consent, and mine follows of course.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: If ever I forgive this.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley has consented (then aside to Lady Bell) He has it; this will gall his pride.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: No end of her folly. I was bent on marriage, but now it's all her own fault. And yet she knows my heart is fixed upon her.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL
sp.p: You are so obliging, and I have so many things to say to you; but if people will not perceive, when they interrupt private conversation.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: If ever I enter these doors again, may the scorn of the whole sex pursue me.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: We have carried this too far.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: The barbarous man, when he should have taken no denial, but have lain on the ground, imploring, beseeching—Delightful! here he comes again.
Is it not strange, that you can't know your own mind for two minutes together?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Ho! ho! the assurance of that reproach!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Appoint your time and place: I must have satisfaction for this.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: To-morrow morning, when the marriage ceremony is over.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I shall expect you, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: This is lucky. I was in quest of your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: In quest of me, Sir?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: In quest of you, ma'am. I have been waiting for an opportunity, and, if the sincerest sorrow can expiate past offences—Here's a chair, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: We may drive him to extremities with Lady Jane: I'll leave you to recover your wanderer.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: If you will permit me to assure you—

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: But while my sister is my rival—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Your sister's charms carry their own antidote with them. If there is faith in man, I mean to attone for what is past.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL,
sp.p: So, so; with what pleasure she hears him? Did you speak to me, Mr. Millamour?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: There was a time, ma'am!— (turns to Lady Jane) Now she wants to interrupt us: don't let us mind her, and she'll withdraw.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Wear the willow, Lady Bell? Not a word, Sir? You are in the right: my spirits are too violent for you; and though what I say is not absolutely wit—Do you like wit? I am sure you ought; for it is undesineable, like yourself.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: That is not ill said.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Horrid! I shall be vapour'd up to my eyes. I'll try my song, to banish melancholly. Where is that foolish guitar?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Now her jealousy is at work. I knew she would be mortified. Let us agree to pique her pride, and probe her to the quick.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Though I can't sing, it diverts a body to try.

l.hi: Sabrina, with that sober mien,
The converse sweet, the look serene;
Those eyes that beam the gentlest ray,
And though she loves, that sweet delay;
Unconscious, seems each heart to take,
And conquers for her subjects sake!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Vastly well!
sp.stage: (listens, smiles, looks at her, draws his chair near her, and beats time on her knee)

l.hi: The lyrant Cynthia wings the dart,
Coquetting with a bleeding heart;
Has cruelty, which all adore,
Flights that torment, yet please the more:
Her lover strives to break his chain,
But can't, such pleasure's in the pain.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Oh! charming! charming!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: What are you about, you wretch? Only look, sister: I suppose, Sir, when you have done, you will give me my hand again.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: I promise you, sister, your triumph will be short.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: How she flung out of the room!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You know, Lady Bell, that I am yours by conquest. I adore you still, and burn with a lover's faithful fires.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Come, and have a dish of tea to cool you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Hear me but a moment. It is now time you should be tired of this eternal display of your power. Your power is sufficiently acknowledged and felt by all. You may triumph over adoring crouds, but one lover treated with generosity, will be more to your honour and your happiness.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Pretty, very pretty! I have read all that in one of the poets.

l.hi: By our distress, you nothing gain,
Unless you love, you please in vain.

sp.p: Come up stairs, and I'll shew you the whole poem.

l.hi: And one adorer kindly us'd,
Gives more delight than crowds refus'd.

sp.p: Will you come? (beckons him) Won't you? Well, consider of it, and when you know your own mind, you may change it again.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: There now! Every thing by turns, and nothing long. Fickle do they call me? A man must be fickle, who pursues her through all the whimsies of her temper. Admire her in one shape, and she takes another in a moment.

l.hi: One charm aisplay'd, another strikes our view,
In quick variety for ever new.

div3.head: ACT the FIFTH.

sp.speaker: MILLAMOUR.
sp.p: AM I to be sacrificed to your humour?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Am I to be sacrificed to your absurdity?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: When pleasantry is out of all time and place—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Why then I shall be tired of all time and place.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Look ye, Mr. Dashwould, it is time to be serious. The wit, that wounds the breast of a friend, is the pest of society.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The passion, Mr. Millamour, that runs headlong without cause, and will not hearken to reason, is a greater pest of society, than all the little with that has been in the world. What does all this mean, Sir? What is it about?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: If I lost money at play, was it for you to carry the tale to my father? for you to subject me to his reproaches?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I don't know by what fatality it happens, but that generally comes last, which ought to be mentioned first. I repeated nothing to Sir John: who did? Do you ask that question? Malvil, Sir, with his usual duplicity.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Malvil? He has this moment told me how pleasant you were upon the subject, and at my expence.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Yes, when he had revealed the whole, and with false tenderness lamented your folly.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! I understand it now. I have been absurd here.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I don't dislike you for your absurdity that serves to divert one: Malvil excites other feelings. You know the character he gave you of Lady Bell.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes, and all slander.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I left him but now, representing you to Lady Bell in the same colours—And here— (shews a letter) Here I have him fast. An anonymous letter against Sir Harry, sent for his own purposes, to Miss Neville. All his contrivance, dictated by himself, and written at an attorney's desk: You know old Copyhold?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Did he pen the letter?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: One of his clerks was the scribe. The young man is now in the House, at my request, and ready to prove Malvil the author. Here he comes —things are not ripe as yet. Say nothing now.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Walk in; you come opportunely.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: If I can be of any service—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: To be of disservice, is your province; and when you have done the mischief, you can transfer the blame to others.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I have been rather off my guard to-day. I am not used to be overtaken in that manner; my head is not quite clear.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Then this business may sober you. What was your whisper to me about that gentleman?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: That he treated with wanton pleasantry what I thought a serious matter. I may mistake the means, but the end of my actions I can always answer for. Sir John might hear of the affair from another quarter, and so to soften his resentment—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You took care to excite it.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I—I—I am apt to carry my heart at my tongue's end.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I knew his heart was not in the right place.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I did not address myself to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I know you have the grimace of character. Mr. Malvil, arm'd at all points with plausible maxims. But which of your maxims can justify the treachery of betraying the secret of a friend? Who does it, is a destoryer of all confidence; and when he attempts to varnish his conduct, with the specious name of friendship, the malignity strikes the deeper: artful, smiling malignity.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I deserve all this. Friendship in excess is a fault. There are bounds and limits even to virtue. It would be well if a man could always hit the exact point. There is however something voluptuous in meaning well.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Well express'd, Malvil! ha! ha! you are right.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: No more of your musty sentences.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Morals are not eapable of mathematical demonstration. And—now I recollect myself—It did not occur at first—It was Madam La Rouge told the affair to Sir John. This gentleman here—I suppose you will take his word—he says she hears every thing, tells every thing, and he calls her a walking news-paper: not that she means any harm. I only mean to say—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Oh! fie, don't be too severe upon her.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: She said at the same time—you know her manner—she told Sir John that you are in love with half a dozen, and will deceive them all, and Lady Bell into the bargain.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Distraction! she dare not say it. This is another of your subterfuges. You know, Sir, how you traduced Lady Bell, and made that gentleman the author of your own malevolence. At any other time and place, this sword should read you a lecture of morality.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: You are too warm: and since I see it is so, to avoid contention, I shall adjourn the debate

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Deceive Lady Bell!—Whoever has dared to say it, —Madam La Rouge lives but a little way off. I'll bring her this moment, to confront this arch impostor.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You'll be sure to return.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: This very night shall unmask him.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I shall depend upon you, Malvil shall answer to Sir Harry: all his artifices shall be fairly laid open.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Mr. Dashwould, we are now good friends, I have reposed a confidence in you. You know every thing between me and Mrs. Bromley, but you see how she goes on.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And I see how you go on. You are the dupe of your own policy.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The Widow's schemes are seconded by your own imprudence. Can't you see, that if Millamour were once married out of your way, Mrs. Bromley would then be at her last stake, and you might have some chance? And yet your son has it in command to defeat my friend Millamour with Lady Bell.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: How! light breaks in upon me. Gull that I was! my son shall marry Lady Jane directly.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: To be sure; and the consequence is, that Lady Bell declares for Millamour.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Right: I am for ever obliged to you: I'll go, and speak to my son, this moment: Lady Jane shall be his, without delay.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: So much for my friend, the Captain: I have settled his business.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Mr. Dashwould, I am so distracted —a terrible business has happened.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Miss Neville! I can't think what is become of her—she is not to be found, high or low. We have searched every where for her. What can be the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Is Malvil gone?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: This very moment: he has no hand in it. He sees, and pities my distress. He is gone to make enquiry. A girl that I was so fond of, and never said an angry word to.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You have been remarkably mild.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You know how tender I have been of her.—What can have put this into her head? How long has Millamour been gone?—I understand it now. This is his exploit.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You wrong him. I will undertake to discover this plot for you.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You can comfort the Lady, Sir; I shall return immediately.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: May I take the liberty, Madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Why torment me thus? You are all in a plot against me.

div3.stage: Enter Lady BELL, Lady JANE, and Capt. BYGROVE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: There, Lady Bell, there is your lover run away with your cousin.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I can depend upon her. I can still venture to answer for her honour.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: She will come back, you need not alarm yourself.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You have seduced her, for any thing I know. I am distracted by you all, and will hear no more.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley, permit me to say a word.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I hope there is nothing amiss. I can rely upon Miss Neville's discretion; I think I can. Come, sister, let us go and enquire. (going, looks back) Hey! you two are staying, to say delicate things to each other.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Our difficulties, you know, are at an end. I have my father's orders to follow my inclination. Had Millamour staid, I have a plot would have fixed him your Ladyships for ever.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And we sha'n't see him again this month, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Let him take his own way. I am only uneasy about Miss Neville at present.

div3.stage: Enter DASHWOULD. (with a letter in his hand)

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: This way, you are wanted: I have a letter here, that discovers all.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: But what does it say? Let us go and hear it directly.

head.stage: an Apartment at Madam LA ROUGE'S.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Have you sent to Dashwould?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Yes, I have send him letter.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Miss Neville here you say?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: She come an hour ago, all in tear.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Then she is safe.—You are sure you never said any thing to Sir John about the gaming business?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Sur mon honneur. What I tell? I know noting. And I not see Sir John in my house, it is two tree month.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You shall come, and confront Malvil at Mrs. Bromley's.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Bagatelle! what go dere for?— Bo, dis is all put me off—pay your littel bill. Vat is money to you? I so poor, you so rich.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You did not say that I should deceive Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Monsieur Malvil, he tell you so?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes; and I tremble for the consequence.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: It is one great villain—I great respect for you. Vous est aimable. Monsieur Malvil, he is great fripon. And I ver sorry he be marry to Madamoiselle Neville.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Married to her?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: You not know it?—He is marry to her dis day. He take my apartment tree week ago. He not have it known dat he is marry for five six day; write letter to me dis afternoon; he must be let in ver private; de servant not to see him; go up de back stairs to her room, and so l' affaire est faite.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And thus he has seduced her from her relations? Let me see the letter.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: I not tink him so bad to talk of me, and tell such parcel of story, vid not one word of true.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: So; here he is in black and white. To come privately, is he? If I could detain him here, and prevent all means of an escape—

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Escape? Up back stairs, he must come thro' dat apartment; (pointing to a door in the back scene) I turn de key in de back door: viola votre prisonier; he is prisoner.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Exquisite woman! I'll lock this door, and secure the key. (locks the door in the back scene) Hush!

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Le voila: he come now.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Fly, let him in; send once more to Dashwould; I want him this instant; fly, dispatch.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: I do all vat you bid me

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: It is honest of her to make this discovery. If this be Malvil—a soft whisper that— (listens) 'Tis he, I hear his voice—I shall have the merit of defeating villany, and protecting innocence—Don't I hear Miss Neville? (goes to a room door) Miss Neville!

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Madam La Rouge!—Oh, Sir! what brings you hither?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: It is your interest to hear me; your happiness depends upon it.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Alas! I fear I have been too rash.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Command your attention, and listen to me: Malvil has planned your ruin.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Impossible: he has too much honour: why will you alarm me thus? I am unfortunate, and you, Sir, need not add to my afflictions.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You have trusted yourself to a villain: he means, at midnight, to gain access to your person; to triumph over your honour, and then leave you to remorse, to shame, and misery. Read that letter. (gives it her, and she reads it to herself) She's an amiable girl, and I dare say, will make an admirable wife—Hark! I hear him in yonder room. Suppress each wild emotion of surprize, and wait the event.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I can scarce believe what I read. What have I done? (weeps) You have led me into a maze of doubts and fears, and there I wander, distracted, lost; without a clue to guide me.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I will direct you: rely upon me.

div3.stage: Enter DASHWOULD, Lady BELL, and Lady JANE.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: La Rouge has told us the whole story.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Hush! no noise.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: My sweet girl, how could you frighten me so?

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: I blush for what I have done. But Mrs. Bromley's cruelty drove me to dispair.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: My dear, all will be well: don't flurry yourself.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Tho' my aunt vexed you, why run away from me?

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. BROMELY, BYGROVE, Sir HARRY, and Capt. BYGROVE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Where is this unhappy girl?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: A moment's patience.

sp.speaker: MIL
sp.p: Is he safe?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: He is dere in de room as safe as in Bastile.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Speak to him thro' the door: now all be silent.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Monsieur Malvil, open de door.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Do you open it, you have the key.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: De key, it is dere: Miss Neville, it is gone to bed; all de house asleep: I in de dark; now is your time.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Hush! here is the key.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Will you dispatch?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Attendez: here is de key: I let you out.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: All in darkness: Is she gone to bed?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: She wait for you: vere was you married?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: St. James's parish: Sir Harry has not succeeded: she prefers me. Say nothing of it yet awhile.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: No; not a vord: tenez, I get light for you.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: So; I have carried my point. The family will be glad to patch up the affair, to avoid the disgrace.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Ah! you look en cavalier; ver good apartment for you; and dere is good picture. It is Tarquin and Lucrece; Tarquin go to ravish de lady in the night. It was villain, was it not?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: A terrible fellow!

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: And dis room it is velle furnish: look about you; more picture, and all original.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! your servant Mr. Ivlalvil!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Hell and confusion!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: There are bounds and limits even to virtue.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Morals are capable of mathematical demonstration.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Let us withdraw from all this bustle. Sir Harry, step this way, I want you.

div3.stage: Exit with Miss Neville, Lady Jane, and Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: This is all according to the fitness of things.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Something voluptuous in meaning well.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Dashwould, your ridicule is now in season to expose such a character. He is fair game, and hunt him down as you please.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Ah! Monsieur Tartuffe!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: The fiends about me!—Mr. Bygrove, you are a thinking man, I appeal to you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I appeal to this letter, Sir.

Madam La Rouge,
Miss Neville has this day given me her hand in marriage. I would not have it known for some time. Conduct me to her apartments, unknown to your servants. The way up the back stairs will be best. Your secrecy shall be rewarded by
Martin Malvil.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: The letter is forged—let me see it.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And I have another proof! this anonymous scrowl, written by your direction, and sent to Miss Neville, to give a stab to the character of Sir Harry. Do you deny it, Sir? Your secretary is now in the house; I brought him with me; he is ready to prove you the author of this mean, clandestine mischief.

sp.speaker: MAL:
sp.p: All false; all a forgery. Where is this French impostor? Where is your witness, Sir? (to Dashwood) I'll put them both to the proof this moment.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: No private parlying.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No; we must all hear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Yes; all must hear.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: My presence may be necessary.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Millamour, stay and give me joy.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: The idol of my heart! To-morrow makes her mine.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Well, I give you joy. Who is she?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: My Lady Bell, thou dear fellow: come, let us go and see what they are about.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Let us go and see who shall cut the other's throat.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: A pleasant employment.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You shall tear this heart out, before you tear Lady Bell from me.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Very well; have your frolic—This works as I could wish.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Despair and phrenzy! if she is capable of a treachery like this—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: You have done some good at last, Mr. Millamour.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lady Bell! (pauses and looks at her) I once thought—but you will break my heart.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: It will bend a little, but never break.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Will you listen to me? There is a tyrant fair, and you have interest with her; you can serve me; all the joys of life are center'd there.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: He is mine against the world. And so you want my interest? That's lucky, for I have a favour to request of you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Is there a favour in the power of man, you may not command at my hands?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: You are very good, Sir; there is a a person, but the levity of his temper—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She means me—Your beauty will reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: May I rely upon you?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: What an angel look there was! And do you ask the question?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: When sincere affection—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: It is generous to own it.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And since the impression made by—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Do not hesitate.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Made by Captain Bygrove—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Made by Captain Bygrove!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: That wounds deep—and if you will assist my fond, fond hopes, —it will be generous indeed.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p:
This is a blow I never looked for—Yes, ma'am, it will be generous, —and in return, if you
will intercede for me with Lady Bell—po! with a— with Lady Jane, I say—I say if you will intercede for me with Lady Jane—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! by all means. And as I approve of your choice, (he walks away, she follows him) I hope you will approve of mine; and by mutual acts of friendship, we may promote each other's happiness.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Malvil is detected.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And Sir Harry has settled every thing with Miss Neville. Go and wish hm joy. (Exit Dashwould) My sweet friend will be happy at last.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: But you won't marry the Captain?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Will you make interest for me?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: How can you torment me thus?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: You have done some service, and you may now entertain a degree of hope. (smiling at him) But have you another copy of verses for my aunt?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: How can you? (kisses her hand; Exit Lady Bell)—She yields, and I am blessed indeed.

div3.stage: Enter BYGROVE, MALVIL, and Capt. BYGROVE.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: The fact is too clear, Mr. Malvil.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: And shall the word of that French impostor—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She has acted fairly, Sir; what reparation can you make the lady, whose ruin you have attempted?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley promised her a fortune, and I have promised her marriage.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And I forbid the banns. Sir Harry has concluded a match with Miss Neville: I should have thought him ridiculous if he had not.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: That you will do, whether he deserves it or not.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You, Sir, deserve something worse than ridicule. You are thoroughly understood. Your tenderness for your neighbour, is malignant curiosity; your half hints, that hesitate slander, speak the louder; and your silence, that affects to suppress what you know, is a mute, that strangles.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: The probity of my character, Sir—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Ay, probity is the word. He has had pretty perquisites from his probity; legacies, trust money, and the confidence of families. For aught I see, probity is as good a trade as any a going.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: The still voice of truth is lost: you are all in a combination.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And you have forced me to be of the number.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley! you will judge with candour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, it is all too plain.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: It is in vain to contend: I shall be cautious what I say of any of you: my heart is with you all.

sp.speaker: BYG
sp.p: Farewel, hypocrite!

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

div3.stage: Enter Lady BELL, Miss NEVILLS, Sir HARRY, and Lady JANE.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p:
Here, Sir Harry, in the presence of this company, I give you, in this friend of mine,
truth, good sense, and virtue. Take her, Sir, and now you have got a treasure.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: It shall be my pride to raise you to that sphere of life, which your merit, and your sufferings from—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Why fix on me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: They are much mistaken, who can find no way of shewing their superior rank, but by letting their weight fall on those, whom fortune has placed beneath them.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And that sentiment, however I may rattle, I wish impressed upon all the patrons of poor relations, throughout his Majesty's dominions.

sp.speaker: Miss NEV.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley, I have much to say to you. My obligations to you I shall never forget. I am not ashamed, even in the presence of Sir Harry, to own the distress in which you found me. If at any time I have given offence; if under your displeasure, I have been impatient, you will allow for an education that raised me much above my circumstances.
