That education shall teach me to act as becomes Sir Harry's Lady, with affection, with duty to him; and to you, madam, with gratitude, for that bounty which saved me from calamity and ruin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Your words overpower me. I feel that I have done wrong. I now see, that to demand in return, for favours conferred, an abject spirit, and mean compliance, is the worst usury society knows of. I rejoice at your good fortune: your merit deserves it.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Why this is as it should be.—Mr. Bygrove, I hope soon to wish you joy.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Compared to Malvil, thou art an honest fellow, and I thank you.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Millamour, is there no recompence for your virtue? in a modern comedy, you would be rewarded with a wife.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lady Bell has more than poetical justice in her power. I wish Sir John were here: he would now see me reclaimed from every folly, by that lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: If it is so, I congratulate you both.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: It is even so, aunt; the whim of the present moment. Mr. Millamour has served my amiable friend, and I have promised him my hand— and so— (holds up both hands) which will you have? Puzzle about it, and know your own mind if you can.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: With rapture thus I snatch it to my heart.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Sister, what nunnery will you go to? Mr. Bygrove, command your son to take her.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: That command I have obeyed already.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Since the truth must out; we made use of a stratagem to fix my sister, and that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: To fix yourself, if you please I knew you would be married before me.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Dashwould, give me your hand. Your wit shall enliven our social hours, and while I laugh with you at the events of life, you shall see me endeavour to weed out of my own mind every folly.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You do me honour, Sir. And, if Mr. Bygrove will now and then give and take a joke—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: As often as you please:—but take my advice, and don't lose your friend for your joke.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: By no means, Mr. Bygrove, —except now and then, when the friend is the worst of the two.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Come, gentlemen, your differences are all at an end. Lady Bell, the varieties of life, till now, distracted my attention.
sp.l: But when our hearts victorious beauty draws,
We feel its pow'r, and own its sovereign laws;
To that subservient all our passions move,
And even my constancy shall spring from love.

div1.head: EPILOGUE.
div1.byline: Written by Mr. GARRICK. Spoken by Mrs. MATTOCKS.

lg.l: IF after Tragedy 'tis made a rule,
To jest no more, I'll be no titt'ring fool,
To jog you with a joke in Tragic doze,
And shake the dew-drops from the weeping rose,
Prudes of each sex affirm, and who denies?
That in each tear a whimp'ring Cupid lies.
To such wise, formal folk, my answer's simple;
A thousand Cupids revel in a dimple!
From their soft nests, with laughter out they rush,
Perch'd on your heads, like small birds in a bush.
Beauty resistlefs in each smile appears:
Are you for dimples, ladies, or for tears?
Dare they in Comedy our mirth abridge?
Let us stand up for giggling privilege;
Assert our rights, that laughter is no sin,
From the screw'd simper, to the broad-fac'd grin.
So much for self; now turn we to the Poet:
"KNOW YOUR OWN MIND"—Are any here who know it?
To know one's mind is a hard task indeed,
And harder still for us, by all agreed.
Cards, balls, beaux, feathers, round the eddy whirling,
Change every moment, while the hair is curling.
The Greeks say—"Know Thyself"—I'm sure I find,
I Know Myself that I don't Know my Mind.
Know YOU your minds, wise Men?—Come, let us try.
I have a worthy cit there in my eye;
Tho' he to sneer at us takes much delight,
He cannot fix where he shall go to-night:
His pleasure and his peace are now at strife,
He loves his bottle, and he fears his wife.
He'll quit this house, not knowing what to do;
The Skakespeare's Head first gives a pull or two
But with a sideling struggle he gets thro';
Darts across Russel-street: then with new charms,
The Syren, Luxury, his bosom warms,
And draws him in the vortex of the Bedford Arms.
Happy this night!—But when comes wife and sorrow?

l.hi: "To morrow, and to-morrow, and to-morrow."

lg.l: I see some laughers here; pray which of you
Know your own Minds?—in all this house but few!
Wits never know their Minds;—our Minor Bards,
Changing from bad to worse, now spin Charades.
O'er Law and Physic we will draw a curtain;
There nothing but uncertainty is certain.
Grave looks, wigs, coats, —the Doctors now relingquish'em,
They're right—from Undertakers to distinguish'em.
The Courtiers, do' em justice, never doubt,
Whether' tis better to be in or out.
Some Patriots too, know their own mind and plan;
They're firmly fix'd, to get in when they can;
Gamesters don't waver; they all hazards run,
For some must cheat, and more must be undone.
Great Statesmen know-their minds, but ne'er reveal'om;
We never know their secrets, 'till we feel them.
Grant me a favour, Critics: don't say nay;
Be of one mind with me, and like this Play.
Thence will two wonders rise: Wits will be kind,
Noy more—behold, a Woman Knows her Mind!
